posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This is the pinnacle of video game controller design. The triggers are second to none, ergonomically curved, perfect travel distance and force actuation with a satisfying click at the end, indicating digital input activation. Indented analog sticks are incredibly precise for the four main directions. Asymmetrical face buttons are designed so you have more real state for the most activated buttons.
Nothing has ever felt so good in human hands.

>>9669293
It has excellent ergonomics, and I like the face button layout. It's very natural because generally in any game you're going to be pressing 1 button a lot more than any others. I'm kind of surprised no one else has tried that.
However it has some issues. Obviously the dpad is slightly too low. It should be closer to the joystick, and you could switch their places too. The dpad is also too small.
The c-stick and Z button are just odd. I don't get the point of having a joystick that can't be used as a joystick but is more like a directional button. I guess it adds a lot of buttons in a simple way. The Z button has an odd shape and size, and there may as well be two of them.
The shoulder buttons overall are inferior to the dualshock style buttons. They are a little bit too concave which makes them just slightly awkward, and go a little too deep which makes them feel stickier than they need to.

Since I got my Fenrir I've been able to start playing through every game that had 3D pad support.
I have to say that when it's done well, it's done really fucking well. Shutokou Battle '97 is a very good example of racing game that uses the triggers and analogue stick more like a modern racing game.
In some cases the implementation defies logic, e.g. Croc. In Croc you need precise inputs and have to play it more like Tomb Raider than a Nintendo platformer. When you use the 3D pad analogue stick it makes Croc run all over the place.
I wonder what the demand would be for an aftermarket 3D pad now.

posts.com:
I don't "opose" any way someone wants to play a game. But I'm not going to pretend I agree that the game is better with these "improvements".

When you grow up you'll begin to respect the original artistic intent and the way the devs and designers embraced the limitations they faced. The coherency of the game's experience depends on these limitations. The art direction was lead with 4:3 in mind. The animations were coded with 30 fps in mind. The textures and models were crafted with 240p resolution in mind.

TLDR: you can continue to tell yourself that you are not missing out on anything by modifying the game in the way you have been, but it's simply not true. I have nothing against you enjoying these changes, but you are wrong about anything opposing it being all about nostalgia

>>9667678
I don't see the problem. If anything I find a second stick more obnoxious because I have to take my hands off of the A and B buttons. I like that Mario 64 is heavily designed around guiding the player without them being forced to manage the camera on second stick, I feel like games designed for a second stick end up lazily tasking the player with it, and so instead of occasionally having to set a specific camera angle (like when Mario 64 occasionally fails to offer a good perspective) you end up becoming your own cameraman and have to fuss with it much more often.

I don't have any problem with the OP webm, and in fact I've used the render96 thing and it's been a cool way to revisit the original, but personally I don't think it's necessary, and I think camera stick games are often times more annoying than games with more guided camera control. Also, I've never been a fan of using right hand sticks, and so I prefer things like goldeneye moving on buttons and aiming with left thumb on the stick. Aiming with right thumb just isn't ideal for me, I'd much prefer using a mouse at that point. I don't expect people to assume this to be a majority opinion however.

>>9667921
>>9667932
You have the right idea, but are going about it the wrong way. You generally want the interpolated frames to be as far away from the keyframes as possible, as they disturb the intended impression of motion less that way. So you'd want to play a 30FPS game at 60FPS, with inbetweens smack in the middle, and a 20FPS game at 40FPS. Moving inbetween frames to be closer to the keyframes is what makes things look much worse.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9667929
Most of the animations in Mario 64 look great with interpolation, but I'd prefer Mario's arms to move more aggressively when running. Moving his hand from point A to B should be frantic, but the delay between A and B cannot really be appreciated if the interpolated keyframe is the mean of A and B—like I suggested earlier, the interpolated frames should be 1/4 or 1/3 of the way there instead of 1/2

>>9665532
I'm sure the Cetra used materia just in the same way humans did on account of them not knowing every little detail attributed to them. For example, Aries can use various magics as her limit break, but she still needs materia to cast "regular" magic. Any particular ancient might be able to commune with planet and know some of its secrets, but they still rely on materia for particularly esoteric stuff.

Not retro, but FFXIV goes with that explanation on its job crystals, which are lumped in with normal materia and auracite, the three being sort of three different degrees of the same thing. Materia has the least or most specific memories implanted in it, job crystals contain quite a bit more, and auracite contains not only the memories of a particular entity but also their pattern and form. If we applied this to FFVII, the black materia is likely a recreation of the specific steps needed to call down meteor.

Though I would say calling down a meteor on the planet sounds pretty odd for planet based magic. It's a spell drawing an entity outside of this world to the planet itself supposedly using the planet's energy to do so, it's not like a localized breech of the natural laws that most magic is. Though perhaps the black materia is entirely different from regular materia, being an entity foreign to the planet just like Jenova is which explains why you need so much energy to use it--planet won't aid in its use, and the only way Sephiroth/Jenova could use it was to suck up a lot of the lifestream and force its use as a conduit for it all.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9667738
Most of FFVII's fantasy is allegorical anyway, with real world comparisons. Mako is a stand in for any natural resource and Shinra is an obvious commentary on the military industrial complex along with increasing corporate influence. For a game made in 1997 it was awfully prescient to point out that big corporations will keep expanding until there's nothing left to compete. How much does Disney own now compared to the 90s? The goddamn President uses Twitter nowadays and Elon Musk causes huge swings in the stock market when he says anything at all. We literally just had a train blow up and poison an entire town in Ohio and everyone in Washington is like "Eh, that's business. MAYBE we'll clean it up." This is all shockingly Shinra-like. The game uses a pastiche of RPG-isms to make it...well...fantasy. But it's making quite a few relevant socipolitical statements about our own world.

They still exist, although exceptionally rarely. I personally find The Desolate Hope to be one of the best "modern" examples of prerendering being used in a game, although part of that comes from being at a naturally higher resolution than previous generations and the skill that went in to drawing the scenes.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9669260
I don't think they're "lazier", more like, the amount of work has increased almost 100x since PS1 times.
As graphics got better, they got more and more expensive to produce. Average PS1 game cost roughly $700k-1.2 mln to develop, for PS2 it rose to $5-10 mln, for PS3 it was at $20-30 mln. One 2022 analysis states that today an average budget of a AAA game is $80+ mln. And the main driver of it all is graphics + advertisement, writing actual code is a fraction of it. some industry guy even said PS5 games will soon cost $200 mln to develop.
that's why companies are cutting corners on everything. they outsource development to sweatshops in shithole countries and use pre-made assets. instead of a company hiring few talented artists, most work is done by hundreds of underpaid pajeets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9669047
Mario 64 largely used pre-existing textures. Your argument is false.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9668473
You can't pre-render a 3D background, meaning that they are limited to stationary 2D games. And if your 2D game tries to do anything fancy like camera rotation, then the pre-rendered backgrounds won't work.

It also looks awful when upscaled.

Pre-rendering is a way to save storage space, but developers today don't really care much about that. They're fine with forcing you to download a 70GB patch just to start playing the game. It's why you only see pre-rendered in indie games today, either people someone wants that aesthetic or wants to conserve storage space for some reason.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: does prerendering just mean using a jpeg as a background image instead of building using models/textures etc?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9669536
Basically, yes. It means rendering something on a separate machine, saving the result as an image file, and just placing the image file in the game. It can be an involved as Donkey Kong Country and Killer Instinct (rendering all the assets, then saving them as the frames for character animation) or as simple as just rendering the background and putting some invisible walls around so you can't walk over it, like the FF9 example in OP.

As >>9669435 points out, you can also pre-render textures for 3D models rather than using 3D modeling and lighting for that effect. Although I don't think too many people mean exactly that.

It's a snes game, first released on amiga or c64.

VIOLENT RUMBLE UPDATE:

UREKKING (rekkre1m1.bsp) is up for testing.
Some notes:
>Rekkr Guy model animations are still very WIP and he doesn't have projectile or gibbed head models yet
>Nightmare might be a little excessive, let me know about balance
>rekkr.wad is available for use, but it doesn't extend far beyond the scope of the map
>N-Rune 5 is now on this map and will be removed from Shub's Wager
>make sure to download the custom skybox in gfx/env
>bare-minimum and untested co-op support

Other updates:
>laser rifle primary damage is buffed, charged shots have knockback, and the projectile now uses the FLY_MISSILE movetype - giving it a bigger hitbox vs monsters
>laser rifle secondary has damage per projectile and ammo consumption halved
>fire shells flames *should* no longer frequently fly through walls, and the max number of flames on a monster is now capped to 10
>biosuit now protects against flames
>lava nailguns now slow down when overheating instead of just stopping and have models indicating heat buildup (might be too subtle, might change later)
>fixed several Gremlin-related issues (and probably created a dozen more)
>axe now has a secondary attack that is slightly faster, but does vanilla Quake axe damage (for not overkilling weak enemies)
>enemies directly hit by a powered Mjolnir have lightning shoot out of them instead of just the floor under them (great combined with the knockback)
>bandolier and time dilation device models updated
>fixed most of the bugs reported over the last couple weeks

As always, make sure to sort by upload date on the Mega so you're just getting the new stuff and don't have to redownload everything. Yell at me if shit is broken.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9666898
I always wished that more FPS games used the objectives style of level design that Goldeneye and Perfect Dark had. Those games are too antiquated for me to enjoy anymore (I know you can play with kb+m, but it doesn't feel great IMO, havent tried since you could first do that though so might be better now), but there's a lot they did right. And I think that objective idea is a great evolution of 90s FPS design with a hell of a lot of room for expansion and improvement. Makes it so you can have open levels and there can be a narrative reason to press switches and get keys beyond just getting to the exit. Could also change the story based on whether you do certain optional or secret objectives, allowing for branching paths without allowing the hero of the game to be evil while still saving the world for some reason.

If I ever get round to making an FPS, that would be something I would aim for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9667243
The remake mod is unfinished and not good, don't bother. RealRTCW mod on the other hand is great, but still very similar to the base game in terms of the overall combat and level design, so you're not missing out on too much. It's not a remaster on the scale of Black Mesa or anything.
Main differences between RealRTCW and vanilla RTCW include:
>increased accuracy across the board for all weapons, but enemies are more accurate as well on the harder difficulties
>new weapons that are all pretty redundant, but some cool ones like a shotgun
>tons and tons of customization in the options, like being able to add in more enemies each level including console exclusive ones, modern widescreen and native resolution support, making your crosshair solid instead of pulsing, being able to have a crosshair when you're not scoped in on your rifle, turning off headbobbing, all kinds of shit
Another cool thing is you can choose which chapter to start with from the main menu, so you won't lose much progress if you switch over now, but like I said, it's not like you're missing out on a lot. However, I would strongly recommend playing on Bring Em On difficulty at most if you play with this mod, as the last two difficulties (Death Incarnate and Realism) are really not suited for first time players as they both lower your max HP.
Speaking of difficulty, the main difference in the difficulties for both base vanilla RTCW and RealRTCW is that on Easy difficulty, enemies have a much higher pain chance and have a slower windup, whereas on I am Death Incarnate, they rarely go into hitstun animations and are more aggressive in their attack patterns. That's why I always recommend for people to play on an easy difficulty for their first-time since it's more fair. Either way, playing on Death Incarnate is totally beatable, and it's pretty cool how RTCW actually changes the enemy behavior to be tougher on Hard beyond just making them more tanky or whatever. Have fun!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9667243
Some RTCW tips and tricks:
1) Basic classic FPS hitscan strategy applies in most situations - break line of sight if overwhelmed. When you do this in RTCW, the basic enemies will often retreat to reload, which gives you an opening of a couple seconds to counter them and be more aggressive. At the very least, it'll reset their windup and allow you to take them down more effectively. If they're especially tanky, wallpeak them and whittle them down first before running in and filling your crosshair with their soon to be dead bodies.
2) Headshots do a lot more damage, so keep your crosshair up around that area.
3) You can lean around corners with the 'q' and 'e' keys. This lets you scope out an area and line up shots. You're invisible to the enemies when you do this, so you can't be shot at unless they enter your non-leaning line of sight.
4) You can hold down CAPS LOCK by default to walk slowly, which lets you stay scoped in with your Mauser rifle while moving, as well as quietly open doors.
5) Crouching heavily increases your accuracy with your automatic weapons. It'll lock your cone of fire to less than half of what it normally is when you hold down the trigger.
6) The Sten does more damage per shot than the mp40, as does the Thompson if you have any ammo for it. Learn to use the Sten against singular foes, so the overheating drawback won't come into play. FG-42 is great too. Flamethrower doesn't do direct damage, but all enemies ticked with it will die to afterburn. Very useful against a certain infamous late-game enemy as well. You can hold down the grenades to "cook" them, letting you release them on the 3rd or 4th *click* to time your throws right.
7) If you're overwhelmed out in the open with no immediate potential to get to cover and break line of sight, strafing horizontally to them while sprinting will throw their aim off a little bit compared to just standing still. You can also strafejump at will even if your stamina bar is at 0%.

>>9667497
There's probably some like that, but it's also a boneheaded comparison to make as BD and HD are EXTREMELY different mods aiming at totally different directions. It's like comparing a car to a boat, if you're looking for one, you're unlikely to be looking for the other.

You could however compare 'production values.' BD puts a lot of effort into presentation, effects, and features, but perhaps isn't 100% solid or well though out in the gameplay at all times, with a healthy helping of jank, bloat, and bugs. Meanwhile, HD has a LOT of depth and nuance to its gameplay, but the presentation is incredibly understated, with its very simple (borderline minimalist) animations, interface, effects, and sound, and with some of the mechanics themselves being a little janky, by design.
Some might say that less is more, and looking closer at some of the cruder design in BD it's easy to say that, but I want to argue that for HD its very simplistic visuals and effects are just less, the way the weapons have the least amount of effort possible put into their presentation really takes away from how they feel. BD may be somewhat lacking in substance, but HD is outright lacking in style.

I get the author is a FOSStard who wants to 'borrow' as few assets as possible, keep filesize minimal, and that he has no artistic background, but I don't think throwing in some royalty free sounds to round out the guns, and developing reload animations slightly, is much to ask. New sounds can be sampled down for size and better matching Doom's own, and there'd be no need to draw a whole bunch of new frames, just adding a bit more motion for the guns and the hands (even using tilting/rotation), won't kill the mod.
There's submods to address SOME of that, but virtually none of them elaborate on animations, either being simple frame replacements or all new added weapons.

I say this as someone who dislikes much of BD, particularly its graphics and sound, while vastly preferring HD's gameplay.

>>9665290
Ranma 1/2's whole thing is that it's a parody of martial arts movies, where nearly every story arc involves a new martial artist appearing using a signature "martial art" and Ranma must fight them. Except the martial arts are all extremely gimmicky shit like "table manners martial arts" where they have to fight while obeying rules of etiquette and stuff.

Shampoo's gimmick was that she specialized in acupuncture and ancient Chinese medicines. And by that, I mean her signature attack was getting behind her opponent, lathering them up with magical herbal shampoo, and hitting their head pressure points while washing their hair to give them amnesia. She was OBVIOUSLY meant to be a silly one-off character, but then the author ended up bringing her back as a regular (except her gimmick kind of shifted from "amnesia shampoo" to "Clingy Chinese girl", so her name made less sense from that point on).

posts.com: I feel bad for American and Canadian weebs growing up before p2p piracy and high speed internet took off. Anime and manga were not mainstream yet in PAL regions, but our TV had a lot of random anime, because at the time, anime shit was cheap to license and dub in French. The Middle East and Northern Africa had a shitton of anime in Arabic, because you could license it for peanuts. France, Italy, and Spain has been jerking off to a lot of '60s-'90s anime on their TV. Shitty dubs be damned. Latin America has an anime boom of sorts by the mid '90s, when all the shonen and shoujo shit hit TV like in Dragon Ball, Captain Tsubasa, Rurouni Kenshin, Saint Seiya, Sailor Moon, Magic Knight Rayearth, Cardcaptor Sakura, etc. The French manga market is still bigger than any other manga market in the west. They translate just about anything printed in shit pape. Don't know if they did any of the ero manga, though, like when in the late '90s and early '00s, you could read Bondage Fairies or Secret Plot officially translated in English.

Game is hoarded. Gets leaked. Hoarder (BakuDD) upset. Mirrored everywhere.
A few years later... Fake name with nonexistent Argentinian address and online lawyer service successfully gets UK trademark for the logo, files for more trademarks on the logo, merchandise, and even the source code.

Those mirrors are immediately targeted and taken down, then videos and tweets and everything about the game. But anything on the Japanese net is fine. Some articles are posted about it. Vinesauce does a video playthrough. Gets /v/ attention, game is mirrored and tons of new videos are made. At this point, copyright troll reads on /v/ that the game has some devs who joined Nintendo later. So he files new takedowns as NINTENDO. He stops for a while. BakuDD crawls out of his basement and denies it's him.
Then he takes down everything except a couple of videos with the most views, biding his time until it all dies down. This time as Ukie, an ESA-type organisation but for the UK.

Some discussion about the lost OST and RODIK websites and datamining happens on /v/. A translation is discussed.

Cue Discord.

Some from the "official Discord server for Cookie Bustle" come to /v/ and announce they're taking care of the translation, and shilling their server. Their invite is present in this video too >>9627917
Discussion about that project fizzles out from /v/ .
In the discord server proper, some progress happens for adding subtitles in the game for the spoken lines and disabling the serial code. They don't have many Japanese translators either.

Turns out:
- BakuDD is in that server
- Apologists for the copyright troll successfully coopted the server
- They also subverted the translation project so that nothing about it being a non-commercial project or anything about RODIK is mentioned because "RODIK aren't the owners of Cookie's Bustle", and want the English translation project to continue in a state the troll (supposed "legit owner of the source code") can sell.

You're here

One example I can think of is Paul Andrews, who is part of a few companies like Retro Games Ltd and Subvert. Responsible for some re-releases of Lynx and microcomputer games. He seems to have made whatever pittance of a licensing agreement you need to with whatever legacy publisher notionally owns some relevant (but not very scrutinized) rights to some random old ZX Spectrum and C64 games which are not exactly hot commodities. You know, for the license to republish, maybe issue a "remake".

One of the more notable examples of this is that his company/companies "own" the rights to the Horace games on ZX Spectrum. A few years back he went on a tear, launching copyright takedowns for anything featuring Horace that he didn't like, including videos by some YouTuber whose content he felt "undermined Horace's family-friendly image." Further scrutiny suggests that the actual rights are murky at best far more limited than he suggests, meaning he likely doesn't even have the right to copyright strike anything. But hey, it's Horace, who's gonna put the money in to litigate against that?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9669272
>I will NEVER understand Sonic, how am I supposed to react to incoming enemies or bottomless pits, if Sonic runs too fast?
1. Have good reflexes, some players will have them, some won't.
2. Memorization, every video game you play, especially retro, beats you up at first, and then once you remember certain enemies and obstacles that gave you trouble, you learn how to get past it and improve.
3. Learning patterns, this is the hardest to explain, but the more you play, the more you'll get a feel for things and will be able to predict when an enemy or obstacle might appear in a level.
4. Roll, literally press down and roll into a ball whenever you can, especially when going down slopes, because not only does it make Sonic go even faster, which is exhilirating, it also makes him less vulnerable to enemies.

>Sonic's jump is pathetic and the enemies placement are frustrating.
What's wrong with Sonic's jump? It makes him invulnerable to most things and keeps his momentum which allows you to keep up with the speed, most platformers have jumping similar to this, I don't see the issue. Now, regarding enemy placement, it's just like >>9669275
said, you can't expect to play and never get hit, that'd be dull in any video game, Sonic is no exception, play, lose, and then play again, like you'd do for most retro video games, and just like you'd expect for any of them, you'll learn and get better with time, be patient and actually try... good luck, OP!

>>9645658
For gen 1 either the Super GameBoy on the SNES or Pokemon Stadium with the Transfer PAK on the N64.

For gen 2, GBC, SGB or Transfer Pak. Gold and Silver look great on the SGB, but if you want to play Crystal on the TV, you'll need the Transfer Pak.

PS. The SGB has a hidden fast speed setting, similar to Doduo/Dodrio mode in Stadium, but you need a special SNES controller to access it.

PPS. Also worth noting, if you have a GBC, is that there's two interesting hacks for gen 1 games: one adds full color to them, the second adds better sprites from gen 2. You'll have a fully colored gen 1 experience that feels fresh, but you cannot use them hacks with a mono GB, SGB or Game Boy Tower in Stadium sadly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Short version:
>play Pokémon red or blue on an OG Game Boy or a Super Game Boy.

Full Pocket Monsters experience: a /vr/ guide
>know absolutely nothing about the franchise and first engage with it through newspapers articles about a cartoon show that caused epileptic attacks on children in Japan
>read video game magazine articles that talk about a social phenomenon in Japan, called "Pocket Monsters", see some small screenshots and design imagen and think it looks weird and foreign but cool
>Call up various local game stores and ask them if they sell this japanese Pocket Monsters Game, only for them to have no idea
>forget about it for a while and one day you casually watch the first episode of "Pokémon" on cable TV and then you keep watching all the first season, meanwhile:
>Get Red or Blue and play on a Game Boy, or a Super Game Boy. Better alternative: GB tower on Pokémon Stadium, and using Oak's Lab for item and pkmn management, much better than the menues on the GB games. But, for a first playthrough it's not mandatory.
>Once you beat the game and catch Mewtwo, watch Mewtwo Strikes Back kino
>Read the "electric tale of Pikachu" manga
>Get a friend or a way to get the Pokémon from the other version that you're missing. Play Stadium's gym leader castle to get starters, fossils, eeveees and hitmons.
>Also try to beat the different cups in the main Stadium game as a post-game challenge. Start training low level Pokémon and buff them/give TMs and customize them.
>Buy at least a pack of the TCG, even if you don't care playing it, it's good art on them.
>play Pokémon Pinball and the Game Boy TCGs if you want somen extra gen 1 experience on GB
>play Snap and Smash 64
>Start reading rumours about pikablu
>Get hype for "Pokémon 2"
>Download a japanese ROM of Pokémon Gold and play a bit of it on a poorly coded emulator
>Play the actual Gold or Silver cart on a GB Color or go full pokemaster and play on Stadium 2 using the GB Tower, then play the Stadium cups.

One way or another, they're killing the whole transfer thingy eventually, since they're shutting down 3DS e-shop by the end of March this year. For now, while you still can, just download the whole Pokemon Bank / Transporter app suite. You won't be able to download and set it up after March. For the VC releases, just download the ROM injects matching the region of your Nintendo account, you don't need to actually buy the games. I repeat, you do not need to buy the games in order to transfer Pokemon, you need the apps tied to your account and that's it.

posts.com: Have a RG351MP but I kinda want to get a RP3+ to replace it. How does it stack up in terms of quality? I'm willing to trade away the metal shell of the MP if the RP3+ is that good, plus it's shipping in Atomic Purple which is a worthy tradeoff

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9669168
I had an rg351mp and bought an rp3+. Ended up selling the anbernic.
The plastic feels good and feels high quality, even compared to the metal body of the rg351mp. I wouldn't want to throw it around like I did with the anbernic though. Much more ergonomic too.
The buttons feel nice, especially the dpad. Totally different feeling from the anbernic. The rp3+ face buttons are smaller, and the analogs are pitifully smaller and worse. The rp3+ also has retarded placement for the select+start. It has much better shoulder buttons than the rg351mp.
The screen is very very good.
It also plays much more systems than the rg351mp, like Saturn and some ps2.
Besides the analogs and button placement, the rp3+ is much nicer than the rg351mp. I think the rg351mp wins for playing older handhelds, like gb, gamegear or neo geo pocket, because the rp3+'s screen feels too big for that sometimes. Also sold my psp when I got my rp3+.

posts.com:
I'm not even playing my Saturn, got all the games for it and finished them back in the 00s, since then I've been letting the games gather dust and go up in value by an order of magnitude. If this continues, I'll be able to retire on my collection.

>>9668653
>anyone got some 2d platformers to recommend? Keio 2 and Astal look fun

Keio 2 is nice for the WTF value but it's really clunky and slow paced. Astal is largely the same, but has no WTF value - once the novelty of "omg huge sprites" wears off, it's just an average to poor 2d platformer.

Earthworm Jim 2 is a great 2d platformer but it's nothing more than you could get on the 16-bit systems, plus it was ported by morons who fucked up the background art. The up side is that it has CD Audio music and the music KICKS A METRIC FUCKTON OF ASS. That is, if you like italian tarantella and Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata. If not, it only has ~2 good tracks (Tangerines and Lorenzo's Soil). Worth getting it as just an audio cd.

Super Tempo and Silhouette Mirage look impressive on paper, but it takes something like 1-2 hours to finish them, and they both have a different gameplay quirk per stage, which makes it really annoying because you have to figure out each level instead of just gunning it through. Great graphics though.

Metal Slug is half as impressive as on Neogeo, it has a fuckton of slowdown (on every single cart, not just the action replay, proof: I have the original disc and 1mb cart). It's also missing a lot of animation, but still has twice as much intact as the PSX port. Up side is the combat school and the art gallery having an extra high resolution gallery. Unfortunately the combat school has a bug that prevents you from reaching the max score and unlock the hidden super dragon mode.

unironically the best 2d platformer on the system is probably Castlevania SOTN, even though it looks like arse and slows down constantly when compared to the Playstation original.

posts.sub: I legit shed a tear to Mighty Gazelle's ending in F-ZERO X
posts.com:
Imagine being an overweight 37 year old autistic incel photographer who doesn't have much friends at your workplace. Your shitty job doesn't give you a really good pay, and live in a poverty 1 room appartment, alone. Your only refuge from this shitty life, as you are nearing 40 are video games, racing simulators, where you casually interact with people online and have couple "friends" you don't really know how they look like because you only talk to them online. You are a kind guy, but misunderstood by the rest of the world, which makes you in real life isolated, while online popular.
Eventually your obsession with cars become too strong that you decide to make it a reality and participate in professional racing Grand-Prix. So you register for the F-ZERO Grand-Prix, in hope for recognition and a better life overall, cause the reward for F-ZERO Grand-Prix is pretty good. announce your online friends you'll attend the F-ZERO Grand-prix, they are hyped about it and see you at the race from the Stands.
The race starts, your gaming skills make you go far in the race, until some asshole bumps your machine violently and crash against a wall barrier and your machine explodes. You are left almost dead.
So a company, Cyber Stick, inc. gives you another chance in life, and rebuilds your entire body and give you a new machine, the Red Gazelle.
You want to race again, in the X Grand-Prix, but your friends you met online are scared that you might die, and already have accepted you as a Cyborg. But you do it anyway. You take part in the X Grand-Prix... and this time... Win. Your friends are happy, having tear of joy that you made the impossible and took revenge in life.

Winning has never you feel so Alive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To give a layman explanation, the PS2 wasn't underpowered but it was difficult to program for and was optimized for really specific computation that most devs didn't really take advantage of.

The Gamecube and Xbox were much more capable of brute force and were much easier to dump high fidelity games onto compared to the PS2. Used properly the PS2 could do a lot of things the Gamecube couldn't and only the absolute top tier of Xbox games (E.g. Doom 3 or HL2) couldn't have run on a PS2.

Dreamcast has twice the VRAM of a PS2 but that's it it gets BTFO'd in every other, more important way.

>Is it true that the PS2 was the weakest console of its generation
No, the weakest is the dreamcast, then the gamecube, then the ps2, then the xbox.

They had their strengths and the PS2 was capable of things not even the Xbox was and this allowed its games to pull off things like particle effects at basically no cost, so developers leveraged this to do all kinds of crazy stuff that even the following generation of consoles would barely do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: If you lived in Southeast Asia as a kid during the 2000s the PS2 was literally your whole childhood. The GameCube did not exist for you and the Xbox was just a Western fantasy that never made its way here. The PS2 had the most cultural impact of any other console, and everyone I know pirated the games, used modchips. They even had quirky fan modded homebrew games where they basically translated the story to the local language like pic related.. To this day, people speak of consoles as "playing PS" as an acronym for the PS2 era. No one cared about the specs, and even framedrops, only that the PS2 outputted a decent enough 3D image to a CRT TV.

Good morning Sirs

Semi related, but the N64 will always be the golden era for multiplayer console games for me. We had the right age. By the time gamecube came around, it was getting harder to meet every week. And with the N64, three of us had the console, so we bought different games so we could exchange them with each other.

We had the most fun with 'Snowboard Kids'. Even more than 'Goldeneye'. Mariokart 4 player was lame, it didn't even have music in 4 player, so you had to listen to annoying buzzing sounds from the karts. Diddy Kong had the music on in 4 player, but it still wasn't very good. Snowboard Kids all the way.
Lylat Wars 4 player was barebones, but we had fun with it.
The king was the minigames on 'Pokemon Stadium'. I'd bought it and found the main game lame. But we used to play the minigames everytime, during our weekly meetup, getting drunk before we went out.
Quake II was a good one too, very underrated. And Micro Machines. Also spent a lot of time on 1080 snowboarding, not even on the twoplayer. We would time trial and then race each other's ghosts.

- Snowboard Kids
- Pokemon Stadium
- Goldeneye

Perfect Dark multiplayer was never that fun to us. Turok multiplayer was fun for 5 minutes. Smash Bros 64 looks like a game we could've had a ton of fun with. We just never knew about it, none of us three with a console had bothered to check it out.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9659368
Part of the point with traditional fighters is it's not just a game of timing and strategy, but also player skill based on practice. Special and super moves are intentionally more difficult to do than basic punches and kicks to balance their usefulness and power. So say, doing Zangief's spinning pile driver. It's one thing to be able to do the move while practicing, but it's another to be able to do the move consistently at just the right time and under the pressure of fightingyour opponent. That is one of the displays of skill at the heart if these games and which makes sense because they're based on martial arts which are 99% practice in most cases.

So taking that aspect away or minimizing it the way smash does, has the effect of making it more accessible, but it also removes a level of skill. It's very much like in cart racing games where the player's ability to win is based more on the meta game of power ups and attacks rather than precise driving in a more sim based racer. So it's not bad, it's just different.

It would be like if you took basketball but gave players the ability where if they are within a certain range of the basket they can hit a button and have the ball automatically go in. It lowersthe barrier of entry for people who want to play basketball because they don't have to practice getting the ball in the net, just running around on the court. And while there is still a game there and skill to that aspect, in the end it's a very different experience.

>>9660575
>Part of the point with traditional fighters is it's not just a game of timing and strategy, but also player skill based on practice
smash has that too without sacrificing accessibility, especially that initial "hook". You can enjoy the game as a beginner and get into training mode if/when you want to get good.
> Special and super moves are intentionally more difficult to do than basic punches and kicks to balance their usefulness and power
combos in smash are intentionally more difficult for that reason as well. There seems to be a huge misconception in the FGC that combos in smash don't exist, aren't hard to execute and/or don't matter, when in reality they're just intuitive, all else still applies. You're nothing without your B&Bs with most characters. A combo considered "easy" in smash: in a specific percentage range, with Mario, grab, throw downwards, and right as the opponent bounces from the floor, shorthop -> up tilt -> up tilt -> up B. The opponent can escape the combo with DI, so you have to follow the direction where he moves as you execute the combo, and you may have to turn that up b into nair or something else. This is WAY harder than a combo you would call easy in SF. People confuse intuitive with easy.
> It would be like if you took basketball but gave players the ability where if they are within a certain range of the basket they can hit a button and have the ball automatically go in.
not really. Hell from our perspective, this is how traditional fighting games are, since with command inputs the character does everything for you as long as you have those inputs memorized. Smash is, like basketball, easy to get into but hell to get good at, and is much harder to predicts. The ball doesn't just. get in the basket if you throw. There's always variability with aim, momentum, etc. I like traditional fighting games, but there's a reason why so many smash players do well in fighting games with 0 previous experience, but not the other way around

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660872
and to clarify, I'm not saying that fighting games don't require skill. Just that their problem of accessibility has nothing to do with skill. I just got into traditional fighting games, and initially it felt impossible to play due to my shitty dpad. Got a good controller and read up on what people use - now what initially felt impossible feels trivial with ZERO practice. That's legacy, not skill. I had to immediately jump into training mode and memorize the b&bs cause fighting games don't really have an accessible beginner pipeline. there's no items mode on to play with experienced players so we all have fun (while in basketball I played a ton of "throw here, then from 3, then half-court" games with my more experienced friends), the inputs can't really be learned on the fly (as you would learn basketball or football or boxing), you have no choice but to commit to the game before you even see what it's about. Unless you've played fighting games before, there's absolutely no reason why a quarter circle -> punch would throw a projectile. It's just not intuitive. That's legacy, and that's the sort of learning path that would've made sense in the arcade days were people met face to face and you could get tutorials IRL. This is why SF 6 will have things like dynamic controls to mitigate this problem - beginners will still lose to the better player, but they can test the waters and maybe even learn a bit.

Executing inputs is not even something I have to think about anymore, now it's all about memorizing them. Where the actual skill lies is in the actual fight - how do you handle neutral, how do you optimize your advantage/disadvantage, which attacks are "safer", how do you read/predict your opponent's habits, how do you mix up and become unpredictable, how do you safely space your attacks, is aggression or defensive play better, etc. All of which is present in Smash, so the skill is the same except without the added complexity of Smash's analog inputs and DI.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I played fighting games on "real" Japanese arcade parts. The kicker is I didn't even know it at the time.
I owned one of these controllers: the Actlabs Arcade Rex.

These use the same switches used by Seimitsu during the time period: the Tokai MM9. With a 24mm button plunger. 24mm buttons were used on older Japanese cabinets during the 80s and early 90s and the AES controller.
The lever is a clone of the same lever found in the Neo Geo AES controller, and is a variant of the design used in the LS-33.
The balltop is a 30mm size just like the AES.

When I owned this stick I didn't appreciate it and wished I had the "real thing" in the form of a MAS stick.

>>9664341
Most models of the SNES have RGB output, but that's not component. You could connect it to something that accepts direct RGB or something like SCART, but you would need a converter (Or cables like these that have an in-line converter) to convert that to component.

If you want to output to a CRT then the Component route is your best bet, assuming you live in the Us where Scart is not common. If your end goal however is to output to a modern TV, then it would be better to just connect it by RGB/Scart to an HDMI upscaler. Even if your modern TV has component inputs, many can't handle the 240p signal the SNES would output through those, or they don't display interlaced frames properly.

NTA but do you have any recommendations from personal experience? Because everybody cares about and documents the converters the other way around, but never the HDMI *to* composite ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9641885
I have been milling about looking at various converters, the only good ones tend be from smaller hobbyist shops that are annoying to acquire easily.

Say you serious and are building a media PC dedicated for a CRT i think the best way to go about it is start with an older AMD GPU(15 bucks on ebay) that has DVI-I or VGA outputs then to converter then to your TV. The reason to use an older AMD GPU is because theres a driver on windows that will do resolution switching between 240p and 480i modes and all sorts of various CRT related settings that makes things work more authentically. This is an almost essential feature when dealing with an an older retro emulator machine because sprites start looking blurry without the proper 240p scanlines

HDMI does not play nicely with CRT from various CRT groups ive read, i think its because theres a floor of how low of a resolution HDMI can go down to which fucks with pixel scaling or some shit. Its just something to avoid whenever possible.

>How does Arcade games on a CRT work?
Perfectly fine.
> is there any limitations on what you can do on a consumer CRT in terms of arcade resolutions?
If it is a 24hz or 31khz arcade game then you will need a CRT that supports those resolutions. Something like a multisync monitor from NEC or Mitsubishi. 31hz is widely supported on basically any PC CRT monitor since it is similar to 640x480 vga.
>Can you even rotate consumer CRTs to play TATE without damaging them?
Yes, no problems.

LCD and OLEDs do not usually have a glass screen. So there would not be "glass in front of glass". There would be only one layer of glass.
And yes, it would help in a number of ways including adding contrast to the image and diffusing the light produced by it in a way that could be potentially flattering. Have you never seen an arcade monitor under smoked (not tinted) glass? Have you ever heard of the term micro-contrast?

But yes, aesthetics are the main goal here. To mask the edges of the 16:9 screen in a more sophisticated way. To have something that looks nice in a game room. These could be very large sizes, you know. Much easier to work with this than a 40" or larger CRT.
Using an OLED the image quality would be outstanding.

>>9647927
n64 only outputs s-video at the highest, so if you want that, then sure, get something with s-video in. you could also rgb mod the n64 or use a clone console or a mister or something to get rgb output (any cable that plugs into the back of the back of the n64 is working with s-video to start out with, even if it outputs rgb). if you do get rgb output, then you can (probably) rgb mod the tv you have already. you might even be able to s-video mod it since it has the vcr. not sure, i only took a cursory look at the service manual. pvms (sony or otherwise) sometimes have rgb in, but not always. usually at least s-video (y/c) though. pvms do have a sharper picture than consumer sets, and that might make a difference sometimes, but anything over 600 TVL won't make a difference if i'm doing my math right based on the n64's 773.5 dots per line. that's probably higher than your tv, i don't see it listed in the specs. it doesn't matter that much anyway. the biggest factor is the input. composite to s-video is the biggest jump in quality from personal experience. no matter what input you use though, the fact is that the n64 only outputs 240p. things like a framemeister can upscale the video signal but upscaling can't add detail, only diminish it. if you really want to be able to see things better, then emulate and render at a higher resolution.

That's so cool. Those don't have any kind of video inputs and only tune into to channels broadcast over the air, unfortunately those are no longer broadcast since the switch to DTT (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_terrestrial_television) so it won't pick up anything. If you have a NES or SNES and an RF cable you could try to hook it up to both VHF leads at the back (even barely touching should transmit a signal), put the NES/SNES switch on channel 3 and then tune on the TV knob into 3.

You turn the TV on by turning and increasing the volume like on old radio sets.

posts.com:
How do I start diagnosing a CRT?
I have a similar model to pic related and the picture looks really bad, kinda washed out and weak, whites look blueish and reds look pinkish, but OSD looks fine.

I tried every repair shop and none of them want to repair a Sony TV. I decided it's time for me to fix it myself, but I have no idea where to start.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9655761
I would start by entering service mode and fiddling with your brightness/contrast/saturation and RGB drives/cutoffs and such to see if it's merely a calibration issue. Also since everything looks washed out, do you also see thin diagonal lines on the screen (aka retrace lines)? If so it could be that your voltage/focus on the flyback is too high and needs to be tweaked down. There's a potentiometer there for that on the back, but you probably have to take off the back.

Otherwise it could be a capacitor issue. Which is generic bullshit advice since that's what everyone says whenever there's any sort of issue. But it's still a likely culprit if you can't identify anything else or fix the issue by just tweaking picture settings.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9662140
>>9662143
To add to that, it was because France (and certain areas of Russia) adopted SECAM while the rest of Europe adopted PAL. RGB was a way of making sure that every european TV could display a color signal. The US had NTSC standardized, which is why consoles here either used S-Video (color seperate from NTSC signal) or component (an expansion of NTSC as a different "dialect" of RGB)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9662140
>I heard RGB mods lessen the life of a tube.
Bullshit. What can happen is a poor mod using a 2-way switch, sending the 5v blank line into the micom, possibly damaging it. Using a crappy switch can also send a static discharge when you touch it, killing the micom.
The only an RGB mod could damage the tube is if you do it the stupid way, by directly injecting the amplified signal into the neckboard, but almost no one does it this way.

>>9661979
I remember not getting a tv with composite input until after the year 2000. The common way to hook up game systems at the time was either through the RF input or by connecting RF into the VCR and then using the composite inputs built into that. I knew only one guy who had a crt with component video back then. Basic lcd tvs offered much better image quality than most people in the USA were accustomed to so it makes sense that they ditched crt as soon as they could.

In this case, the instructions are telling consumers who were most familiar with RF that they could get better picture quality if they used the composite inputs.

What speakers do you recommend

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9667208
Honestly everything will be better than a TV's mono speaker, but if you're looking for a bargain, then I'd go for some vintage stereo amp and speakers. If you omit the flagship audiophile models (those have skyrocketed in the recent years, the retro craze affects everything), you should get a decent setup for real cheap.
I'm rocking a mid-range Denon amp from 1989 and ESS bookshelf speakers from the early 80s. The whole setup cost me less than 400€ and it's great for music and games (to be honest, anything that's good for music will be good for games, too). If anything, maybe I'd change the amp for something warmer sounding, maybe a tube one.
But if you just want something for retro games then you don't even have to spend that much, just look around for some old amps and speakers from popular brands. One thing to remember though, unless you want to place the speakers relatively far from the TV, you want them to be magnetically shielded.

I think it's made pretty clear that the Cyborg is a proxy for the player himself, the "god" of the Marathon universe who can die repeatedly, jump across several alternative timelines, and with tools like Forge and Anvil, create entire new worlds and scenarios forever.

Durandal, being aware of its own limited existence within this contained constructed simulated universe, uses Machiavellian manipulation to wield the Cyborg/player's god powers with the intent of ultimately escaping the simulation, but by the end of Infinity, Durandal has at last accepted that such a thing is impossible.

>>9667085
I can’t think of anything interesting desu, just the usual stuff.

We’ve had a couple of gen cycles now and can see a pattern—shit goes from new ($60 in release) to old ($7 a few years into the next gen) to retro (back up to $30-40 two to three gens later) and then one by one games shoot up to stupid prices as the secondary market takes notice thanks to youtubers etc. One recent victim is the Futurama game, which was affordable even after the 2020 market spike until recently

I never sell anything so my personal stories are just bragging about shit like getting Popful Mail for $25 (and almost not spending that because it seemed like a lot) or the local game shop letting me sort through their Saturn disc onlys and walking away with a collection worth over $1,000 today by spending like $30

>>9667136
We actually were discussing this in the collector shitposting thread. NES games on the whole are back up with the market since 2020 but were on the decline before that as interest shifted forward in time.

Everything before 3rd gen isn’t really part of the cycle imo. 2600 games are for the most part just too basic. Anyone can sit down and have a genuinely good afternoon with Mario 3 or Castlevania, but its hard to find a reason to play Yar’s Revenge these days outside of curiosity. There are some exceptions like River Raid.

So NES is kind of the canary in the coal mine for this cycle. We’ll see if they die out dirt cheap or go back up as the 20-year fad cycle rotates once again.

Modern developers are trying their damndest to phase out physical games as a whole so that will undoubtedly have an effect on the market, but who knows what.

>Rakugaki Showtime.
How does this shit work? Want to give it a fair chacne but no idea what to do. Is it all about parrying and grabbing objects like in many Treasure games?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9668345
Think of it as Power Stone, but with a main dodgeball mechanic as its primary focus (kinda like this anon >>9665594 described it as), main objective is to drain the enemy's health (in adventure mode the enemy's health is indicated by the color of the outline, going from white for full health to red for no health, while in multiplayer mode it shows like your hud in adventure mode, with a pencil that shrinks). You can parry and throw objects to do some damage, however you also have some melee attacks that you can perform with the square button + the direction of the dpad (even if the main four characters' attacks aren't that powerful), usually the meta is to farm the ball from yellow to red until its outline becomes a rainbow, where then you can perform special attacks that can do massive damage once you grab it, these special attacks are also done differently depending on what direction of the dpad you're holding while the character holds the special ball for those 3 seconds that happens. Trying to unlock every character legitimately is a fun little distraction that you can do (specially if you play it on either a PSP, a phone, or one of those chinese handelds where you can pick it up and play after you wake up your device from sleep mode), and i'm sure that playing with other people is the best way to enjoy the game, as some sort of party game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
We all love Disney, or at least most of us do, it's something that pretty much every kid out there grows up with and either becomes a huge fan or is at least fond of it looking back. Of course Disney isn't an entity focused on bringing joy or anything like that, though many people there had that intention back then, and maybe even today, but still, a company has a single true goal, making money and staying on top, and a way to do that is expand into different markets to make more money somewhere else. In the late 80's and early 90's Disney truly caught on to video games and their growth, and we got many gems thanks to that.

I'm mostly familiar with SEGA's Illusion series, which is what I grew up with, on my good old Mega Drive, though that series also had plenty of releases on both Game Gear and Master System, which I've played now that I'm all grown up and thoroughly enjoyed for what they were. I didn't grow up with just Mickey and Donald though, there were also tons of video games based on Disney films, like The Little Mermaid and The Lion King, which are the ones I remember most fondly, though there were many others like Aladdin. Disney's video games kept being made when the jump to 3D happened, on PS1 and N64, and quality was still good.

Nowadays though... we've got Kingdom Hearts and not much else, so if you're not into that series then there's not much to see, back then when Disney would put out a new film it was a matter of time before we got a video game adaptation, regardless of how good or bad they were, we had them at least. Of course, this could all change with the new Disney Illusion Island, for Nintendo Switch, it looks like a modern World of Illusion and I'm really into that, hopefully it lives up to the name. Anyways, what are your main experiences with Disney video games? How do you feel about them overall? What were your personal disappointments and your favorites?

Here in Netherlands Donald Duck comics are still hugely popular. The weekly magazine still has lots of readers. Many of those comics were created here but I remember Denmark being home to most Donald Duck creators.

Supermarkets and bookstores also sold separate series in pseudo-hardcover named after main characters. One of them was 'Dagobert Duck' (Dutch name of Scrooge McDuck). When I was a boy I was blown away how good the comics from this series were especially compared to the weekly magazine. The first them I read one I was so surprised how different it was. Only later I found out the 'Dagobert Duck' series were all translated works of Don Keno Rosa.

posts.com: I didn't grow up with Castle of Illusion, just QuackShot, but knowing that the team behind one of my favorites had made Castle of Illusion before it, and World of Illusion after it, I had to try them all out... in the end Castle of Illusion became one of my favorite SEGA Mega Drive titles, it just did everything right for a licensed mascot platformer, and even more than that, you could feel all of the love its creators had for Disney and its history. I've been wanting to try out Castle of Illusion's 8-Bit port for quite some time now, and even though I did play it before, I'm only now giving it a proper playthrough. One thing that immediately turned me off, which was in the original aswell, is limited continues, though you have 9 of them here, you still can get a Game Over, being sent back to the title screen, which I always dislike. Anyways, at first things just weren't clicking, its changes to how it played were welcome, like the grabbing and throwing of things, but something felt off, it just wasn't as fun to play and level design felt cheap sometimes... still, I kept pushing and now I'm at a spot where I can clear the first few levels easily and while gaining a lot of Tries, I think this is what so many love about retro video games, how something feels so difficult at first, and then suddently you're good at it by simply playing more, I'm having fun.

>>9668487
An update, I've managed to actually complete it, both its Master System and Game Gear versions, because I wanted to see if I could find any differences, they were there, but barely noticeable and relevant at all. I'm glad I've played through this, it's not as good as its original 16-Bit version, not at all, but it's still excellent in its own way, especially for the hardware. I love the art style they went with, while the 16-Bit version went with a more iconic Mickey look, this went with a more classic one, with the completely black eyes, similar to his first few appearences. Also, while it keeps the stomping mechanic, it adds the whole element of grabbing and throwing objects, and it's used so well... I'm impressed with how much fun I had playing this, the level design is superb for a 2D platformer, it looks nice, sounds nice, controls nice, it's all you can really ask for. I did struggle a lot on the final level, but as usual with retro video games... I got good at it by simply playing that very level over and over when losing, and eventually mastered it, only the final boss still gives me trouble, a lot in fact, but I can do it after a while. I loved it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Many great games loved and played to this day, so how come it didn't it sell that well?
posts.com:
Personally, I always theorized it was a zeitgeist thing: It was the 2000s; a lot of the hype around the new consoles was founded on giving us photorealistic graphics. Many people, including many Nintendo fans who had grown up, yearned for mature stuff like in the movies most popular at the time (Matrix, Saving Private Ryan, Lord of the Rings), while Nintendo, silly as they are sometimes, went out of their way to make franchises like Mario and Zelda look more colorful and childish than on previous consoles. The GameCube's biggest draw was good controls and gameplay in 3D games...which was already the N64's gimmick

I can only speak for myself, but I remember the GameCube generation being the time where I temporarily cared less about gameplay and a whole lot more about cool presentation. It took me a while to rediscover Nintendo and have so much fun playing Melee with friends and finally giving Wind Waker the chance it deserved

There are a lot of contributing factors, some say the overreliance on their own games or the lack of a DVD player, but, from my own experience, my own changing interests in my teens were the main reason I wasn't sold from the start. I assume a lot of fans skipped it entirely and waited for the Wii with Twilight Princess and backwards compatibility

Anyone else here who got the GameCube several years after its release and had a lot of fun after initially not caring or prefering other systems?

>>9665394
A strong focus on marketing to young (<10 years) kids is what really fucked them over. They intentionally cultivated an image that the Gamecube was for kids, from the small discs to the controllers to the color scheme of the console itself. First party stuff like Luigis Mansion, Super Mario Sunshine and especially Windwaker coming off the heels of more mature Zelda titles were all clearly aimed at elementary school aged kids. There were a few standouts like Metroid Prime but those kinds of titles were really the exception. RE4 was the only "must have" title that was marketed towards an older audience and that got ported to the PS2 pretty quickly.

Assuming the gaming audience was largely born between 1985-1993 for the Gamecube's generation, it's easy to see how it got hamstrung. You play Mario on the SNES as a young kid, you play Mario 64 which is a great improvement when you are getting into being a tween and then the GC comes out and it's more of the same stuff you played when you were in elementary school.

Meanwhile the PS2 was marketed and perceived as a direct continuation of the PS1, with the idea that the audience who had played it when they were in elementary school would in turn continue playing their console as teens. Outside of the obvious advantages of having an inbuilt Hi-Def CD player and DVD player it's early must have games were largely continuations of more mature franchises. Armored Core 2, MGS 2, Tekken Tag Tournament, Gran Turismo 3 were all "your favorite PS1 title but even better" and easily appealed to people who had played those titles when they were younger. You didn't feel like you were playing a game marketed at little kids if you played MGS1 and then picked up MGS2. If you went from Majora's Mask to Windwaker it definitely felt like you were too old to be playing that kind of game.

posts.com:
At the end of the day, it didn't even matter how great or unique the game are. The competion had games that were also great; it was a solid generation. But the 18-30 audience had become much more important for the VG market, and the GC was just the worst console to take to a college dorm or have as a normal young guy even though it had a lot of party games.
DVD culture in the 2000s was also huge. If you were a young adult/teenager back then, you were buying movies, borrowing/renting, trading, etc. It was the era of rediscovering 30 year old movies, of college kids having Scarface and Godfather posters.
The GC was cheaper for most of its run, but the PS2 having a DVD player, plus much cheaper games and a larger back catalog.(Player's Choice GC games were like $30, Greatest hits were $20 or cheaper)
By 2004/05 you could walk into gamestop with $20 and buy like 4 or 5 iconic, major PS2 games. That's how mass produced and cheap they were. I still have some old PS2 used cases; DMC was $3, GTA VC was $5, MGS 3 was $7, shit was insane. If you were in your teens/twenties on a budget, PS2 was the most reasonable console.
Plus the whole image issue. PS2 had many more games looked more mature. Of course there were plenty of adults who played gamecube too, and I'm sure people here will say they would have smash parties at the dorm or whatever...but that wasn't the norm. And PS2 had all the games that really broke across pop culture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9636792
>if you rewind before you got hit.. did you really learn how to dodge that attack?
Yes, because if you don't learn how to dodge it then you'll just get hit again and become stuck in a rewind loop until you learn how to not get hit. It's actually a much faster way to learn.

Without rewind, you either take the hit without dying and keep moving forward having learned little-to-nothing until next time or you die and restart the entire stage and have to replay until you get to the part where you died and try not to die.

With rewind, you get hit and then immediately rewind so you can analyze what hit you and why, then keep rewinding until you know exactly how to avoid it. It's the same practice loop as above, just done immediately instead of spread out over a long period of time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638054
The post I originally replied to literally says:
>i eventually learn to beat it because i'm picking up on stuff and applying learned muscle memory to this difficult situation.
Which is all much more quickly learned through immediate repetition. It's the difference between improving your free throw in basketball by throwing 100 free throws each day and improving your free throw by playing an entire game of basketball each day. One gives you distinctly fewer repetitions of what you're trying to improve. You need to practice the whole game, too, obviously, but these individual fundamental skills are best improved through maximum repetition. If you want to master dodging a specific boss's attack then the best thing you can do is rewind repeatedly until you've got all the cues and timings down. Practicing the game as a whole is a separate thing with a different practice method.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9640856
Is it mental gymnastics to say that throwing 100 free-throws in a row is better free-throw practice than playing an entire game of basketball? The latter will take significantly more time but offer significantly fewer chances for a free-throw. If you want to practice beating one specific section of a game, it's better and faster practice to repeat that section over and over than to restart the entire game each time.

To use a more video game oriented analogy, competitive fighting game players go into practice mode and repeatedly practice inputs for the same move or combo repeatedly for long stretches of time. That way when the pressure is on during a real game they're less likely to drop their inputs. Playing a whole match is also practice, but if you want to practice one move the best thing to do is just repeat it over and over, same goes for rewinding a single segment repeatedly until you have it down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In my opinion save states are only acceptable in the following circumstances:

- For NES era games that lack a saving function or credit system. Using a save state at the beginning of a world / set of levels instead of starting over from the very beginning.
- To suspend your game and pick up where you left off (like leaving your console on overnight)
- As a replacement for passwords as they can be a hassle to put in

Otherwise it's unacceptable. Rewinds are always unacceptable for obvious reasons, as there also isn't a cognitive learning process if you instantly rewind. Your brain won't learn the patterns like that, despite what some people claim here.

Fastforwarding in JRPG's is understandable, especially for the NES era. But I avoid them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653032
>Did it not occur to you while writing that training modes akshually make you worse
Not sure what you're referring to. All I know is that when you instantly rewind, there won't be a cognitive learning process as your brain needs to learn (adapt to) a certain pattern with expectations and outcomes. Rewinding just brings you back to the moment right before dying, but not the moments leading up to it. Yet you'll still receive the dopamine reward in both cases, taking away the motivation to become better at the game. Rewinding also drastically reduces the possibility of failure, and failure is when your brain actually learns in order to adapt and overcome. Hence the absence of learning.

8 and 16 bit games especially have been designed with this learning process in mind. It's the literal structure of those video games. When using save states or rewinds, you bypass this learning process and don't experience the game in full how it was intentionally designed by the brightest minds of the gaming industry. What you're left with is a powerpoint slide of dopamine shots that only serve as escapism. The element of 'play' almost completely disappears. Imagine soccer but every time a player misses he can rewind and slightly adjust his foot to make sure he'll get the right angle this time. What is left of the game then? Nothing.

In short, rewinding makes you a worse gamer in the long term. This is simple cognitive neurology, any scientist would agree. Save states and rewinds therefore make for an objectively inferior experience as you only experience a small aspect of the game. It's only slightly different than being a passive observer by watching a longplay on Youtube. It just baffled me how some people don't see this. I said my peace.

>>9663106
if you don't know how to solder then don't bother you'll probably mess it up, desoldering really isn't that easy and you risk destroying important parts of the board by using cheap irons that run too hot.
It's not incredibly difficult either but it takes time and effort to get right, also a good iron, flux, and solder, because the best way to desolder something is by adding flux and fresh solder to it first. From the power board you're only removing one screw and desoldering two points, I believe. You could also add resistors to the GDemu to achieve the same effect
https://www.delta-island.com/index.php/en/tutorials/gdemu-power-supply-mod
or to the power supply itself. If you install them at the power supply you don't even need to solder them in, you can twist them up and connect them to the right points with friction on the power supply pins, so that's probably your best bet if you don't want to learn soldering. Pic related. I do not recommend doing it this way, as if it becomes dislodged you could create serious problems. Soldering is best but I'm showing you this so you understand this can be done without soldering, if you're willing to take the risk.
Your Dreamcast is going to run hotter without modification definitely. I don't recommend leaving it that way, it may not be 100% necessary to do but heat is bad for components, could you find anyone that knows how to solder? If not you should learn to do it by practicing on junk first.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9663231
>Some people say get it with lead while others say lead free and it needs to be a certain mm or something
I use tin/lead mix solder, alpha fry rosin core, it's great quality, just don't breathe it in or inhale any flakes if you're using those cheapo desoldering pumps because lead can fuck you up.
mm doesn't matter so much for the entry level hobbyist, at the end of the day you're melting metal to metal, it's all molten before it hardens, thinner mm can offer more control over how much you flood a joint, or for when you need exact small amounts of solder to not bridge anything. Obviously use thinner mm for smaller joints or joints with less clearance if you don't want to have to clean up excess solder mess because thicker mm like 0.7 - 1.0 can more easily flood or bridge joints. When desoldering the power supply components in the Dreamcast mm isn't really something you need to worry about. If using the desoldering pumps seems a little too complicated, like you don't have enough hands to do it, try using desoldering braid. I've had more luck with the pumps on average though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9667791
>Any tips or advice?
keep a set of fresh diapers and spare controlelrs nearby

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Get a guide ready if you're stuck because the game can be obtuse on purpose and will make you replay the same parts over and over again until you give up.
And don't expect it to be like Resident Evil or even Silent Hill. There's really nothing much like this game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9667791
Follow a walkthrough. I would never normally suggest this to someone playing a game for the first time, but Siren is pretty much unplayable without one. The obscure sub-objectives you have to complete in each level make Wizardry 4's puzzles look fair and reasonable. If you're averse to using walkthroughs, like I am, then play a different game because you aren't going to enjoy Siren.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9667927
Will keep that in mind. The story seems terrifying, as well something about an alien entity crashing into a Japanese village during the height of a famine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9667927
I think ithe ideal way is to start playing "fresh" to not get spoiled, and then look at a walkthrough when the levels start looping to actually know what the fuck you're supposed to do to progress.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9667791
Play without guides until you actually hit a wall. It won't happen until a few hours into the game. The game becomes less scary when you figure out tactics, so cherish the dreadful first hours of it.
Second mission teaches you sightjack - you can see the world through the monsters' eyes. Once you tuned into a monster, press a face button to assign the monster to it. It stays when you restart the mission, saves you a lot of time when you keep restarting a difficult mission.
The game does have a lot of cryptic shit, but I had lots of fun exploring and experimenting. Reminded me of Hitman games.
If you won't like the first Siren, give Siren 2 a chance. It's a significantly more approachable and overall better designed game.

>My main memory of Apocalypse was the pain we all went through.

>It was a hugely ambitious project and used a mix of rendered and hand drawn artwork from a variety of graphic styles (which didn't always work - although all the individual bits were great).

>Probably the worst fit was Tim White (an established SF artist) who had been commissioned to do the character designs. I like Tim's work, but his models were intensely detailed and quite unsuitable for reducing to the scale needed for an isometric game of this type.

>The creatures he designed looked great full screen, but reduced to the size they would be ingame they were often unrecognizable blobs.

>I don't know the reasons behind the descion to hire him, only that the problems were apparent to everyone in the art department, and I would have loved to have seen them ditched.
>I'm ashamed to say I was responsible for the green worm in Apocalypse, the worst ingame sprite I've ever drawn. It was frankly impossible to create it while keeping it accurate to the original.

>Scanning the models was tried, but was next to useless, and most of the ingame images were based on handcoloured photos of the original maquettes.

With Magnetic Ion Armor, you can float around and not get grenaded by Lobstermen--in the original game aliens are dumb enough to throw grenades at flying soldiers but they don't do this in OXC anymore. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9666975
About alien colonies. In part 2 the aliens all spawn in the northern half of the map so you can just avoid that area. The command center is always beneath the engine room so you can locate it easily--sometimes it's in the north of the map which is bad because there will be Lobstermen and Tentaculats up your ass. Just drop a grenade to blow up the command center and run for the exits. The 50 Zrbite is in the engine room but you'll have to shoot out the sections of the floor where it's located to get at it (which needs a Sonic Cannon shot or two).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653749
Everything about TFTD I enjoy more than UFO defense. The subtle differences between land and sea battles (fires going out quicker, smoke only obscuring vision and not suffocating characters, making it viable for cover), the more consistent theming of aliens compared to the seemingly random amalgam in UFO Defense, the aquatic environments themselves and the aquatic designs of the enemies, the generally weaker weapons, emphasizing the terrifying menace of the aliens better...All of it, EXCEPT:

Lobstermen. Fucking Lobstermen. The one singular glaring flaw in the entire game, which negates an entire technology tree because of how common-place they become, and how early they begin becoming common-place. You can basically throw gauss out the window unless you are going for a very specific playstyle. There is virtually no reason to not go all-in on Sonic weapons early. Playing the game without editing the files to change Gauss properties or Lobsterman properties makes it a chore. I would recommend installing mods that improve gauss if anyone is interested in playing TFTD for the first time.

>>9653010
Anything you want to have shortcuts to on the system menu should run from the memory card, I think. In my experience trying to start apps from a system menu shortcut can make the system lock up if the HDD has to spin up first.

If you're concerned about memory card space you shouldn't really be using your FMCB card for game saves anyway. Best to just load up all your homebrew onto one card and use another one for saves (or a virtual card on the HDD)
