posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9664635
https://github.com/MechaResearch/MechaPwn
If you have a SCPH-500xx phat and you're ntsc-u you can use mechapwn and play burned discs perfectly.

Use genuine non cmc taiyo yuden (marked as jvc on the packet) or another brand like verbatim cd-r that doesn't lag on fmvs (might have to test some quality cd-r before you find the right type, as I said the gold standard is no stuttering on the fmvs). First when you get the iso downloaded check the md5 against redump. Use iso burn, set md5 reporting to on in the settings, and compare the burned disc md5 to the original on redump as well.

The games play perfectly this way, well fairly well when it comes to pre 75000x. Popstarter is a piece of shit and waste of time. You're better off emulating at that point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9668432
From what I've read an SSD will not give you any real performance improvements in games compared to a hard disk. It might help with the speed of some homebrew menus. But that's really only an issue if you've made specific mistakes in the set up process of your drive. Or if you're constantly adding new games one by one and then want to rescan for the new titles instead of doing one big badge. SSDs probably also offer slightly lower temps, power draw and are ofc quieter - but most HDDs aren't that loud anyway.

Just make sure to create the +OPL partition on your HDD right after formatting the drive and don't any games before that. Otherwise OPL menus will allegedly run slower the more titles are placed between MBR and +OPL. Because every game gets put into its own partition. Also, never delete games off the hard drive.

>>9667890
>Sheldon's game
Hari Seldon is a fictional character in Isaac Asimov's Foundation series. In his capacity as mathematics professor at Streeling University on the planet Trantor, Seldon develops psychohistory, an algorithmic science that allows him to predict the future in probabilistic terms. On the basis of his psychohistory he is able to predict the eventual fall of the Galactic Empire and to develop a means to shorten the millennia of chaos to follow. The significance of his discoveries lies behind his nickname "Raven" Seldon.

In the first five books of the Foundation series, Hari Seldon made only one in-the-flesh appearance, in the first part of the first book (Foundation), although he did appear at other times in pre-recorded messages to reveal a "Seldon Crisis". After writing five books in chronological order, Asimov retroactively added two books to expand on the genesis of psychohistory. The two prequels—Prelude to Foundation and Forward the Foundation—describe Seldon's life in considerable detail. He is also the central character of the Second Foundation Trilogy written after Asimov's death (Foundation's Fear by Gregory Benford, Foundation and Chaos by Greg Bear, and Foundation's Triumph by David Brin), which are set after Asimov's two prequels.

>People have said the games were all shit when they were released
it was ok for 1977 standards, however the 80s were not that forgiving and it was dangerously out of date several years after release. computing tech was evolving at a rapid pace and atari truly believed they could just keep releasing shit. atari were right, people were still buying enormous amounts of shit, but that bubble was about to burst. also, arcade machines were improving greatly after 1980 and people were comparing what they saw at arcades to the experience at home and could see how inferior it was.
>Amazing that Bushnell isn't a Jew.
yeah, quite amazing, but he did a lot of jewish things. such as: trying to claim credit for inventing pong, which he stole from magnavox. bushnell and atari were sued and lost. every pong machine atari sold, or any pong clone, magnavox got a cut of the profits and made Ralph Baer very rich.

I saved one from the garbage a few weeks ago.
I do have some fondness of playing my parent's 2600 in the early 90s as a little kid.
This one I found. I cleaned it up, took it to work and tried to get others just to play. I work with mostly 18-24 year olds. The reception was very hit or miss.. mostly miss.
I get many games you cant play for long. I think of it like flash games. You may not play them for hours on end. They are perfect at giving 10-15 minutes of joy and then you move on.
Some games I could paly for hours though. Pong, centipede, joust, kangaroo, and combat are my go-tos.

Also I started dabbling in programming for it. Holy cow do I have mad respect for anyone that ever made a game for the 2600. Even the ones that typically get shit on like ET or the pacman port.
I've only got "hello world" and moving a dot on a screen down, but it anyone knows of any good resources I'd love to know. I have a few Atari-tier games I would like to try to produce for the world to enjoy sometime.

This guy's art fits that same idea, maybe. Like it was ok once on gunstar heroes, and maybe mischief makers was a fluke, but otherwise it's to the point of detracting from the final product.

Chunsoft developed the first 5 games + Torneko's Mystery Dungeon. Yuji Horii only worked as the writer/scenario designer of these games. Horii is absolutely part of what makes DQ good, as you can see from the creators he collabed with on DQ6-9 utterly failing to make good RPGs without him, but Chunsoft was massively important to the games before 6 and got fucked.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9660109
The remaster is fantastic and the most accessible legit way to play the game unless you have a GameCube copy or manage to get your hands on a copy of Trilogy. The visuals and controls are great, and the sounds, music, progression, map layout and overall content are 1:1 to the original, unlike the Dead Space remake. Essentially, if you play the remaster, you're getting the full experience, and a good representation of it at that.

If you're a purist and want something closer to the untouched experience, download PrimeHack for Dolphin and play the Trilogy through that. Also a great way to play all three games. But keep in mind that the Trilogy lacks some of the minor touches the original GCN edition had.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660146
The new controls are certainly more intuitive, but the game was originally designed around the more involved aiming controls and stuff. So when you play the remaster with twin stick control, it's super fucking easy. Like I am on Normal and have not come even close to dying at any point. I think the remaster supports a control option that mimics the original though, but I haven't tested it. It also has the Wiimote aiming controls if you're into that. If you have a Switch-compatible GC controller, it can be used to control the game exactly as it was on the original hardware. Visually the remaster is exceptional, and runs at 60FPS somehow despite the Switch's dogshit hardware.

Ultimately, I would recommend the remaster without any caveats, unless your mission is specifically to play the original code of the game in its purest form. The remaster is a straight visual upgrade without sacrificing any of the original's art direction or atmosphere. Control options are varied enough to give you whatever you want. It's got extra accessibility options, and some bonus features like concept art and 3D model viewers that the original didn't have.

TL;DR The remaster is definitely worth the purchase

people have some sort of autistic fit over unbranded/generic/non-official/aliexpress cables but 98% of what makes analog video cables good is proper shielding and wire thickness. I have some generic n64 to composite that were thinest possible wires with zero shielding that picked up all sort of interference but then the generic 5 dollar S-video to n64 were great and on par with high quality cables. It really just depends on whatever chinese factory decided to use thicker gauge and shielded cables that day. Sometimes they will use good stuff despite it being generic chinkshit.

i will always hunt down cheapo aliexpress shit first, most of these retro consoomer brands are just reselling the same shit with their label slapped on it for a stupid price. unless there is some sort of advanced circuitry going on inside it like the gamecube component cables.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
there's 3 tiers for s video cables:

shit tier - the ones with the yellow cable combined. Not true s-video

good tier - standalone 3rd party s video cable. Look for thicker cables, they usually have better shielding

A+ tier - Official cables. Best quality and shielding but it will cost you.

no reason to settle for shit tier

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9665690
Wrong, objectively, on virtually every regard.

Horror is the realization that life is not what it seems, and that there is a threat beyond your purview. It's why there is a much more "horrifying" reaction to finding eviscerated corpses in a field of flowers on a bright sunny day, than finding an eviscerated corpse in some grimey war-torn battlefield. On a battlefield, it's to be expected, something that circumstance dictates as the norm, but in a lovely nature-esque field on an other-wise normal day, it becomes a jarring warning, something that alerts the individual to some danger they were previously unaware of. Horror has a much more visceral feeling than the mere common-place "raping" of one, which occurs daily and quite often within the animal world, in fact it is really only a subject within human society to classify "rape" as something altogether different from sex at all. They are one in the same.

Horror though, even animals can feel horror. It is far more powerful, dangerous, and unnerving of a feeling than some petty unwanted sexual advance. But, alas, a simple mind such as yours cannot comprehend the depthful, archaic, primordial feelings one associates with true "horror". They instead retreat to the more easily understandable positions which they see as reassuring because they can "know" their fear. But you won't know it, because you can't know it. It's a subconscious feeling triggered despite any training, exposure, or knowledge.

This is not to be confused with terror, which would be more equivalent to your *ahem* "low intellectual analogy" to rape. Terror is the realization and knowledge of what is happening, but is the anticipation of it about to happen, such as being chased.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9666971
Panic is a loss of one's mental faculties to think rationally or intelligently, and is generally a mental state. Terror is specifically in regards to the certain situation, which may instill panic in the subject.

Horror = Unraveling of perceived reality

Terror = Anticipation of a threat acting upon you.

This is how it's always been since the conception of the genre hundreds of years ago. All the emotions can generally be described as "Fear" though. Fear of a rapist is not the same as fear of a predator. One is merely an aggressive act, the other is an existential threat. I went to college for this and got my degree in Sociology, so I've been through the various differences between intense emotional states of humans, having been required to take a few psychological courses. The other anon is verifiably speaking from the nonsensical gender theory perspective, which has zero basis, as all the writings are veritably based on personal interpretations, not theory analysis and empirical research from psychology journals.

>>9664821
Sunshine. Sunshine to me is one of the best 3D platformers of all time, if not the best. I feel like I'm the only one in the world who thinks this nowadays. Every single complaint I've heard parroted for more than a decade now sounds like a ridiculous exaggeration.
>muh chuckster
the one level where you gotta get tossed by two chucksters isn't RNG as people imply. It took me 2 tries.
>muh watermelon level
beat it first try. Didn't even take long. Fun tension. Why the fuck did people get filtered by this?
>muh Pachinko level
I beat it in less than 3 minutes. Seriously.
>muh lilypad level
I'll admit that just getting there is unnecessarily tedious, but it's completely optional anyway. The level itself was fun.
>muh blue coins
who cares? there's really no reason to get them anyway.
the only truly tedious parts of this game are the boat in the lava level near the end, and the manta ray boss, neither of which get any complaints online. I wonder why.

anyway this game is creative, very unique and experimental, and somewhat janky but genuinely fun. There are few parts, if any, that feel like mindless braindead easy platformer for the sake of it, something that other highly acclaimed platformers suffer from but no one who likes this genre seems to mind when the games are too easy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9666219
It's not just nurbs (UE's nurbs support is also kinda arse), it's also how they're animated. Modern character animation pipelines for these engines require a skeletal armature rig for animations, something that wasn't available for the software used, or was implemented in a way that modern systems won't recognize.

All those changes to get your models into a modern environment will amount to remodeling and re-rigging the whole thing. At that point you're better off making a new model loosely based on the old one.

>>9668985
I suspect that Light built X because of how Rock was clearly having emotional problems from all the fighting and Light had a crisis of conscience. Rock was never meant to fight. He was basically Light's son. He volunteered to be converted to Mega Man because the situation with Wily needed to be dealt with and there was no better alternative at the time. But after Mega Man 7 it was obvious things had taken their toll. Light built X hoping he would be able to live in peace but built him to be battle ready just in case from the start. And comparing the two shows how they differ when it comes to battle fatigue. X will distance himself and cool off when things get too much for him. Rock meanwhile will double down and just power through until he either dies or snaps. X did some fucked up things in service of the Maverick Hunters but he never threatened to murder a guy who at the time was on his knees. Light built X with a better ability to handle the stresses of war.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9657904
I've been playing it for the first time, albeit with a lot of familiarity from seeing my friends play a long time ago, and it's the most fun game I've emulated in a while. The "survival horror" tension is incredibly effective. Every time I enter a new room my ass is clenched listening for zombies because I don't want to get bit or waste bullets. You don't know what's going to come next, especially when there are enemies like giant spiders that you wouldn't necessarily expect to be in a zombie game. And on top of that the game is extremely well designed so that you can anticipate what comes next based on the items you found in the area you're currently in, due to familiarity with games in general, but you still don't know exactly. So it creates a very satisfying give and take where you feel like you're using your brain to survive while at the same time reacting in the moment to the unexpected.
It's also interesting to think about how this was the game that started the franchise. I know all about Umbrella and the t-virus and the characters etc. but if you played this game when it came out that would've been completely new, off the cuff, no big plan to create a franchise that would spawn a million more games. You would have no idea that there was a laboratory hidden under an elevator disguised as an ornate fountain, it would've been mind blowing. Fucking sharks in the water.
The cutscenes look great too. And it has replay value, enough that you could play it at least 4 times, then more if you want to do challenges which give cool unlocks.

all of you going in the right direction, but i will explain to the real reason that no one ever touches upon

classic RE games are movie games done correctly simultaneously through gameplay. it just looks like you are playing a movie because NO FUCKING MOVIE TAKES PLACE IN 3RD PERSON OVER-THE-SHOULDER-VIEW which is today's meta for "movie games" with narratives and such

anyways, the most important thing is the dynamic camera angles in classic RE. they were inspired by the camera angles they were experimenting with during the french new wave era of film. those camera angles were considered fresh and really experimental back then and they changed the course of film to this day.
those camera angles can
>display hidden items (sometimes, only the player can see it and not the character; i think this is really good)
>point the player towards points of interests and where to just progress
>tell bits and pieces of story and lore through it's atmosphere alone
>can actually hide enemies (which is a really good alternative for jumpscares people always complain about)
>display the really nice interiors of the buildings in the games
all without saying a word; then you throw in bits of cutscenes to round the whole story out. the horror genre, in general, benefit from these kinds of camera angles and it's really evident in classic horror films like night of the living dead.
another influence was film noir and with the old police station aesthetics in RE2 and 3; all with irons art collection that just made it better

it quite literally looks like you are playing a stylish movie. movies have camera angles. i thank god no one in japan was able to make a 1st person shooter back then because that's what mikami initially wanted for RE1

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9660908
It really depends on what you want the shader to accomplish. Some are more complex than others and emulate more facets of a CRT, while others are more simple and are made essentially to set them and forget them. That said, most of them are designed to be tweaked to your liking, so if you don't like how one looks right off the bat, you can usually go into the shader parameters and fiddle around and see if you can get it to look more pleasing. Speed may also be a factor if you're on a potato rig, and there's shaders for that, too.

That said, my recommendations are CRT-Guest-Advanced if you're a tweaker, as it has by far the most options and is still actively developed, CRT-Easymode if you just want something that looks alright and don't much care for parameter fiddling, and crt-gdv-mini if you're on a toaster, followed by zfast_crt if even that one is too slow, but we're talking memeberri pi levels of shit here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9665459
There's an element of that, but I think shader artists are trying to square a circle as best they can. What it comes down to is CRT being at its core an analog technology. It affects everything, even how frame rate works (modern monitors literally pause and hold the frame, they don't blast the field in and out leaving an afterglow the way a CRT would). The fidelity of the image is only limited by that of the human eye and the capacity of the tube. If you tone down the visibility of the scanlines to account for people seated at a healthy distance, then you get what probably just looks like a mild bloom effect. It's like trying to get the polaroid you took to look like the oil painting you saw in the museum. At the end of the day you're still looking at a polaroid and not a painting.
Something else people don't mention often is that it's one thing to imitate a CRT in a still image, but it's quite another to do it in motion. And I think that's almost certainly impossible for the above reasons. The concept of frame rate is very different for a CRT to that of an LCD. There are people trying to do black frame insertion on monitors with very high refresh rates and quite frankly that level of autism is too much for me.

Makes sense. Wouldn’t there be some logic in trying for a mild CRT effect? Generally people just line double when playing on an emulator which gives an EGA/VGA sort of look but that seems inaccurate because the pixels are 480P size and every other line is blank. However the brighter pixels blend together to some degree, so trying to emulate this effect might be more accurate then simple line doubling. What is term for this, bloom? Seems like a good thing to approximate and not worry about creating intricate shadowmask or aperture grill simulatiors.

Personally I just have a 1080P display so I just line double and turn my sharpness down, but the idea of being able to use 4K shaders on an oled when I acquire one intrigues me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9665749
With ideal implementation and settings backlight strobing works very well for motion clarity but the flicker at 60Hz is somewhat harsher on bright solid colour blocks than a CRT. Nothing I can't overlook having grown up on 480i and games like GT4 with white menus but it's there and you don't want to look at white web pages or text editors in the dark particularly. But to get it perfect at any refresh it definitely kills brightness, which once again I can overlook because I am a cave dweller with my monitors turned down low anyways, and old CRTs without the brightness/contrast whacked up are not exactly the brightest things out there either anyways, but it's also something.

In general features to do a fairly good impression of a CRT exist but they aren't all together in one monitor let alone a practical or affordable combination of hardware overall.

The penalty lasts as long as the effect does.
If the effect is permanent the score penalty is permanent. Sub tank elves, max health increases, etc.
If the effect lasts for one level the score penalty affects that level. Healing elves, the A rank elves (which change the letter to A but still negatively impact the numeric score), etc.
None of this applies to Zero 3 where you can use two satellite elves permanently with no penalty, or get all your elf effects for a small penalty by entering Cyberspace. Ditto for Zero 4 which is basically like having three satellite elves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9662417
If you unpack an ISO and then just casually repack its contents into a brand new ISO, chances are the formatting will be nowhere near what a PS2 game is actually expecting, and PCSX2 will then shit its pants when you try to run it.

What I can recommend without getting into software that you have to pay for to spoof disc formats and such, is a little bit of patience and a hex editor. Specifically, HxD if you are on Windows. You can use HxD to directly modify the ISO contents without completely screwing the formatting up. Just copy paste the new file contents in and you should be set. Things could get complicated if the file sizes do not match though, so watch out for that. I would recommend to minimize chances of breaking things that you use the Tools > Open Disk Image option rather than directly opening the ISO.

MML is fine. It's not a shitty game. But the graphics, controls, variety, characters, pacing – EVERYTHING – gets a huge boost in MML2. In fairness, a couple things MML1 does that MML2 lacks:

2. Whole world is interconnected (all dungeons and the town above), which doesn't improve gameplay per se, it's just kind of neat.

>>9660163
It's Black Matrix 00. What a fucking weird series this is though.

Black/Matrix - Saturn - 1998
Black/Matrix AD - Dreamcast - 1999
Black/Matrix + - PSX - 2000

Black/Matrix II - PS2 - 2002

Black/Matrix Zero - GBA - 2002
Black/Matrix 00 - PSX - 2004

Weird seeing Ryoko Shiraishi and Nana Mizuki in a PSX game, but it was the last new Japanese game for the system. I mean, releasing PSX games after the PS2 was out was not a totally unreasonable thing to do because of backwards compatibility meaning you were purely expanding your install base, but that's so deep into the next generation for Japan after they'd already made a PS2 game in the same series. But the PSX port coming after Dreamcast was already an odd start.

Which one of these 3 do you think would be the best for a complete newcomer to the genre? Also is it SRPG or TRPG? Thank you.

Final Fantasy Tactics A2 is even more flexible if you go for the DS.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Probably Fire Emblem GBA. It has an excellent tutorial for anyone new to SRPGs and is one of the best games on the system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SRPG is a Japanese abbreviation (of English words), "Simulation RPG" -- it came about because the term "war simulation" was the genre term for war games in Japan, and for whatever reason the word "simulation" rather than "war" came to be used to abbreviate the genre. Then when they added named characters & experience points to it they called that a "Simulation RPG"

TRPG is an English abbreviation, "Tactical RPG" It came about because people thought SRPG stood for "Strategy RPG" and they didn't like that that didn't match the content of the games, which are about tactics. Either that or because Tactics Ogre and Final Fantasy Tactics were popular.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9638217

https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/シミュレーションロールプレイングゲーム

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638146
Of those three, I think the best game is Fire Emblem GBA (FE7). But Tactics Advance is really a much different beast, it has a larger focus on story and granular control over your individual units, with you training them up in various jobs and specializations much more similar to RPG games, whereas Fire Emblem is much more simply focused on being a war game, like chess or something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'd like to use a new term that applies to almost all FE games.

Puzzle Tactics game.

It's a "tactics" game where the emphasis is on "solving" a level by doing a very precise and rigid set of moves with very little room for improv.
To that end FE games tend to have side-objectives that emphasize rushing towards a part of the map where some unit is doing something on a "timer" so you have to immediately move a certain way with certain units to reach it. Also the weapon triangle makes it so very specific units can defeat other ones which are statically placed so you have to send a certain unit a certain way to accomplish that. Also the weapon triangle makes it so using a wrong unit can have them wiped out in even one attack, which reinforces the "correct" way of doing things and minimizes improv.

Games that would fit in this sub-genre are also Advanced Wars and (not retro) Into the Breach.

An example of a non-puzzle tactics game is Tactics Ogre, where you have more control over your party customization and loadout and the enemies can be defeated in a more fluid, back-and-forth way. Certain maps where you recruit special units are tailored mostly towards rushing them a specific way, but these are generally rare and special cases. In general you can flop around, lose some units, recover, and legitimately use "tactics" to win.
UFO and XCOM are also "true" tactics games.

My point is that the game forces you into a very narrow "problem-solving" approach both in map layout, units given and so on... certain units are specifically designated to defeat certain opponents and you almost always have to use them that way.

In "true" tactics games like XCOM or Tactics Ogre you are given a far more broad approach in dealing with situations tactically, rather than treating levels/battles as problems to solve a very specific way.

>>9646353
>why are there so many tactics ogre/fft clones but so little fire emblem clones?
I suspect it's for the same reason that there are so many Castlevania clones and so few Metroid clones. Namely, that the majority of people don't fully appreciate the subtle differences between the two and so anyone asking for Metroid-like games is pointed toward Castlevania-like games as if it's all the same. Similarly, anyone who asks for Fire Emblem-like games is simply pointed to FFT-like games instead.

I think it comes from one game just being more popular than the other so that's what gets copied most and then people who don't respect the nuanced differences between the two don't drive any demand for copies of the less popular one because they don't even see a need for it.

>>9656819
>Well that's a perspective I've never heard before and does make the idea of just skipping to FE3 a lot more appealing.
If you only want to touch any form of that game once, then yes skip to Book 1 of Mystery of the Emblem. I will say there is a magic to FE1 that no other FE games have that I feel warrants at least one playthrough, though the inventory system might be frustrating to deal with as it is admittedly clunky. But there's a magic to playing the games in order of release and seeing the evolution there. Otherwise you would have to play half of a SNES game, go back to play Fire Emblem Gaiden on the NES, then go back for the other half of the SNES game to play in order of "1, 2, 3" for the games.
The inventory system might of the original Shadow Dragon might be frustrating to deal with, though. Even when the game wasn't even a year old yet there was an interview with the series creator on Famitsu and he talked about how people complained about that inventory system. So in the SNES remake he listened to the criticism and he overhauled it to be more easy to use and far less clunky.

I've not played all that much FE but that doesn't match my experience with them at all. Maybe on those really hard difficulty modes all the new games have now, but not on normal or hard in the older games.

They tend to have so many more playable units than there are deployment slots people just use their favourites and send everyone else to the bench, so it's not as if you're forced to use specific characters much.

And sure, you could argue those characters aren't always that different statistically, but you don't need to use especially specific class compositions either. You probably want a few staff-users and cavaliers, but when it comes to things like knights or archers, some people love them while others can't be bothered with them, and both get by just fine. You can take very different teams into the same map and come out on top. Not to mention sometimes a unit dies and you have to adapt to that. Sure you can reset, but not resetting or only resetting for really painful losses are definitely supported playstyles as well.

Regarding Advance Wars as well, maybe you only meant single-player, but AW has a big multiplayer community as well which doesn't seem plausible were it really a puzzle game.

>Is that really how millennials felt about the game at the time? Even though FF7 had the chibi models???
Basically, yes. Western gamers were obsessed with percieved "maturity", and they based it entirely on visual cues. FF7's "chibi" overworld models were largely ignorable because the battle models were properly proportioned, and the overall atmosphere of the game was still rather gritty and realistic. Additionally, FF7's marketing made it pretty clear it was trying to be a "mature game for adults" whereas FF9's started out by focusing on the fantasy aspects and characters; people saw a cartoonish knight, a dopey mage, a faggot with a tail, and whatever the fuck Quina was and they could feel their masculinity disintegrating.

>>9662081
A lot of reasons many have listed, but I think the biggest thing about VI that makes it so good is the major event midway through. The first part of the game you are simply trying to stop an evil empire from gaining more power through magic. You have a LARGE amount of characters gained each with a unique story. But at that major event, the world is torn apart and there's nothing but tragedy and loss. The second half involves you finding your friends to reach that final boss, who is in many ways, a better villain than Sephiroth.

You have to take into consideration that this event has a message for almost every single playable character They all have different motivations, but imagine LOSING everything and your entire world has come to an end. What would you do? Would you search for new meaning? Would you try to rebuild? What if you can't because everything around you is falling apart? Would you try to reunite with your loved ones and find new meaning, charting a new path to rebuild the world as you know it? That is the World of Ruin. Getting everyone together and the experiences along the way. They all have meaning. They all have life and yet Kefka wants it all to become a monument of non-existence because he sees life as meaningless. But in the end, they triumph and can bravely step into this now magic-less world together.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As someone who played Shadow a lot growing up and still has a lot of attachment to the game, its pretty fucking bad for a variety of reasons:
>cringe edginess blah blah you already know this
>does not balance shooting and action with speed mechanics, at all. Shooting accurately means stopping dead, so levels are never designed around high-speed freeform movement.
>atrocious fucking hot garbage voice acting, 4kids dub is completely indefensible especially coming off of SA2B and further flanderize already thin characters
>many levels/objectives are atrociously designed, with extreme repetition, 'kill all X enemies', bad slow platforming with no flow, arbitrary timed missions and 'shoot the fucking thing for 20 minutes until it dies'. You will usually do all of these things twice in each playthrough
>No specific level stands out as enjoyable, nearly every level is some flavor of tedious or outright unfun
>on top of that, every level is visually disgusting. Bad post-processing effects and a terrible color pallette make the game look like mud
>bosses are mostly shit and get repeated over and over to fill out the arbitrary number of missions/routes
>the story is completely fucking fumbled due to the arbitrary route progression, as events and characters do not logically flow together. This ruins what ideas could have legitimized this otherwise very over-indulgent game
>I can't remember any of the music from this game whatsoever besides that fucking bike bell in the first level. Honestly, I'm pretty sure the music or soundscape in this game causes some kind of mental trauma or overstimulization
>Licensed tracks absolutely got watered down. The most interesting part of Sonic Team's temporary relocation to the US West Coast was their involvement with the music scene, but many of the original acts intended to supply licensed tracks (Magna-Fi, Sins of a Divine Mother, Mona Lisa Overdrive) got ditched and we got worse replacements as a result
>the multiplayer. Just try it

>>9667269
Mario Odyssey has a lot of optional levels that are very challenging, some of the hardest in the entire 3D Mario catalogue I'd say. A lot of them are locked behind the postgame (thee's dark side of the moon but also darker side, and every kingdom opens up a bunch of additonal levels) so most people don't even notice. Just like the hard levels in Sunshine, the ones in Odyssey make you want to make use of Mario's moveset beyond the simple run and jump. Very fun and rewarding.

regarding 3D Sonic, take SA2 for example, the only one I like despite being mediocre. The sonic levels are decent, but most of the time you're just on a rail-esque run that doesn't require a lot of thought unless you're aiming for a high rank, except when you're in a janky part of the level that makes the camera move weird and you don't even know what the fuck is going on, then suddenly it's hard for a few seconds. Falling to a pit doesn't feel like your fault most of the time since it's not like you could've predicted it with such speed. Still fun though. Then there's the Tails/Eggman levels. The platforming is absurdly simple, the gun autoaims for you and kills everything in side, and there's really nothing to do but walk to the end of the level and hope it's over soon. Then there's Knuckles/Rogue levels, where the core gameplay itself is just a long, boring, tedious "hot! cold!" treasure hunt. I'd call these levels irredeemable trash if flying to the music didn't feel so satisfying, cause really that's the only good thing about it

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9657201
>Game was wasted on N64.
Yes and no.

From the developer's perspective a visual novel was a low cost way to push software onto a new platform.

However, from the customer's perspective...An expensive cartridge that also required additional hardware was a hard sale. In 1996 people still hadn't accepted memory cards as a standard peripheral yet. As a consumer it simply made more sense to buy a cartridge JRPG with battery backup rather than whatever the fuck this was(a low spec PC game that required a separate memory card basically.)

>But the game came with a memory card!
Yeah but not for free. Did you mother fuckers forget having to pay as much or more for a memory card when it was an emerging technology? Eighty dollar video games except you can't save your progress because you also have to buy this separate piece of hardware for an additional fifty dollars and with tax you're now paying one hundred and forty dollars for this visual novel slideshow.

So basically a third of the price of a console just to play a watered down version of Princess Maker on emergent technology. Precisely why there wasn't a Wonder Project J3. Back then people couldn't justify paying so much for so little.

They tried to decap a NES CIC chip, it didn't work out, and so they just filched the patents for it and made a clone chip. In fact to this day the NES CIC has never actually been reverse engineered and not much is known about its inner workings; all Flash carts use a clone of Tengen's CIC chip.

Most unlicensed devs did other tricks like shocking the CIC chip with an electrical charge to knock it out, and Nintendo repeatedly modified the NES to prevent this from working--the last run of NESes made in 1991-92 were heavily fortified against CIC defeater devices.

>>9661507
I just finished Atari 50 and it's actually pretty interesting
They put these like Proctor and Gamble execs in charge of everything, and it's easy to heap blame on them because they objectively didn't know what they were doing, but to their defense there was no roadmap before them to show them what to do and not to do. Like there was no consumer electronic that had a lifecycle the way that a video game console does.
So they basically
-didn't know not to flood the market with shovelware, because execs didn't know a good game from a bad game and good game and only cared about total units sold, not understanding how much damage they were doing to their brand
-didn't know how to sunset the 2600 and introduce the 5200. Which again, to their defense, a proper console lifecycle had never been rolled into the next console's lifecycle before, and it's a minefield of confusing people and alienating consumers. And of all the lessons Nintendo and Sony learned from Atari this is the biggest one. Sega uh... could've learned this lesson better.
-It's too broad of a statement, but they really didn't understand the marketplace and how some people chased graphics, some people didn't care, some people wanted a fullblown home computer, some people didnt care, etc. So genuinely the smartest thing Atari ever did (in my opinion) as a hardware manufacturer was way after the 1983 crash when they cut the 2600 down to like a half it's size, and sold it for way cheaper as the Atari 2600 Jr. Because yeah, then you can get all these people who aren't chasing the hardware specs under your umbrella, who are going to buy your software (where the money is), and might get grandfathered into the next gen.

Anyway I'm just repeating what the game said, so take it with a grain of salt. I just think it's interesting how most of the subsequent manufacturers learned from Atari's mistakes and the whole Nintendo moratorium on publishing too many games is a good example of that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9661389
>In fact to this day the NES CIC has never actually been reverse engineered and not much is known about its inner workings
It hasn't been decapped, but it's pinout is known, all registers are known, and it's code has been dumped and fully disassembled. We know what it does, and how it does it. It's pretty much a tiny 4-bit CPU with it's own tiny work RAM and 512/768 bytes of ROM, and the ASM code on the ROM takes the handshake from the cartridge, wrangles it through, and then sends the reset(or not) on what it calls P1(Pin 9 as per NESdev wiki) to the console. Decapping it wouldn't really be of much use unless we are going for transistor-level accuracy or "gotta emulate every last detail 100% correctly even if it tanks performance" MAME-level accuracy.

Acclaim created the company Flying Edge, which would publish Genesis/ Sega games exclusively. Flying Edge was a division of Acclaim, and Arena was a division of LJN. But Acclaim purchased LJN and all of LJN's subsidiaries. in the end, Acclaim owned LJN, Flying Edge and Arena Games. Jack Friedman started fresh with THQ. Tengen was a division of Atari Games. Atari Games was owned by Namco at some point, then sold to Midway, and then Midway went out of business and was sold off in chunks to WB games, with some of the sports properties being sold off to EA. >>9663206
>always heard that other unlicensed games tend to shoot extra voltage into the NES, and 'daze' the NES10 lockout chip. They can damage the console, and even causes a burning plastic smell. The TENGEN carts use some sort of reverse lockout that doesn't do any damage.

There was other unlicensed games that did indeed do that. It was found that if you sent a voltage spike to the chip it disables it until you power cycle the console. The NES10 basically does the equivalent of pressing the reset button if the other chip on the cart ever fails it's security check (Hence why the NES keeps resetting if there is no cart inserted), so disabling it works for bypassing the DRM. The Famicom never had it, so it could not be integrated that well into the console unlike later Nintendo systems, which is why just simply removing the pin from the chip that sends the reset signal disables the DRM completely instead of prevents the console from working at all.

No idea if it could cause damage, but it likely was not good for it. I think Codemasters was one who did that, there was a switch on their earlier carts that adjusted this behavior because it was not perfected. I think later ones removed the switch because they revised the method so it worked on every model successfully.

>>9663805
It wasn't really a lockout system, it was called the TMSS, the TradeMark Security System. Basically the Genesis would check if a text string of "SEGASEGASEGASEGASEGA" was present in specific locations in memory. The development documentation of the Genesis actually mentioned that games should do this, some ignored it because it didn't seem to do anything.... until SEGA made it a requirement in later revisions for the game to boot. The idea being that "SEGA" is trademarked, and a game would basically be violating their trademark if it sent that text string to the console without their permission and they could sue. Eventually exactly that happened, SEGA sued.... and lost because it was ruled that nobody would be able to see those 1s and 0s making up SEGA's trademark being electronically sent to the console to make it boot so they can't reasonably argue it's trademark infringement.

The whole "security" system depended not on any sort of DRM, anyone would have been able to bypass it, the dev documentation even said how to, the whole system depended on it being possible to sue anyone who does... and the lawsuit failed.

Nintendo actually did something similar with the Gameboy. That Nintendo logo that appears on boot is actually a security check, the image is being sent from the cartridge and if a single pixel is off it won't boot the game. The difference here is that you ARE seeing the trademarked logo so if it went to court it would likely have been ruled in Nintendo's favor.

Eventually a flaw was discovered though that it reads it first to determine if it passes or not, then reads it again to display it, so some realized they could send the proper logo then quickly make the cart send THEIR logo when it's read again to display it. Argonaut demonstrated this to Nintendo and got hired over it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9664340
>Nintendo actually did something similar with the Gameboy. That Nintendo logo that appears on boot is actually a security check, the image is being sent from the cartridge and if a single pixel is off it won't boot the game. The difference here is that you ARE seeing the trademarked logo so if it went to court it would likely have been ruled in Nintendo's favor.
that also failed pretty hard as bootleggers were able to work out that they only needed one part of the logo's tiles for the gb's bios to verify it as legit. nintendo were always shit at security, and nothing changed in the switch era. it's always amazing to hear stories about nintendo crying about their "intellectual property" when the NES is just a reverse engineered clone of Ikegami Tsushinki's donkey kong arcade board.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The original PS had a metric shitload of games, and in spite of growing up with it, I never played THAT many games for it (had maybe 15 PS titles). Recently I've been revisiting the console and there have been a lot of fun lesser known games I've been playing.

Lucifer Ring is a sword and sorcery type 3D beat em up, a little basic and by the numbers, but some of the bosses are awesome and beat em ups in this old world setting aren't too common.

Brigandine is a very flavourful strategy game with a fantastic art direction and sense of style. I guess with games like Final Fantasy Tactics on the system, Brigandine was bound to be overlooked, but it really is great.

Also been playing Ape Escape. That's not really a niche title, but I've never played it before. It is very impressively polished and well thought out, just in general. I'm looking forward to checking out the other games in the series.

If you have any recommendations, let me know. Otherwise, just post about the PS below. PS2 is cool too.

Not only are they unrelated, they aren't even the same "Ivalice." Its role in the FF franchise is more of a theme or template than a physical setting, with no hard-and-fast chronology or lore.

I think it was a good idea. It makes the gameplay more focused and it's great for the atmosphere. But I can understand the ones saying the game was too expensive for how little game you got. But I think it makes up for it in quality over quantity.

The lack of enemies apart from the bosses made the emptiness feel more peaceful too, which was a nice change of pace from the bosses, but also increased the feeling that maybe the colossi weren't so malevolent.

And all the empty space made it feel like you actually were an explorer. If Columbus had stopped at islands with towns littered across the Atlantic every day on his way to America he wouldn't be exploring, he'd just be globetrotting. Whether that kind of exploration is fun or has any place in a game can be debated though, it's definitely not for everyone.

>>9660713
There are better sites, which have more strictly curated abandonware with well designed launchers - like TCC. Myabandonware is curated, and there are hundreds of links to paying sites for many games now, but there's so much content on here that it's always going to be behind.

In terms of the 'is it legal/is it not' - no it's not legal, but rather than being "illegal" it's what one may consider "unlawful" - i.e., it's unlikely that anyone is going to do anything about it, . Similar things for instance would be the 'street drinking beer in paper bag' example from the Wire - Police don't want to arrest you, but it's illegal - if they can't see it they don't have to arrest you.

The police or your ISP certainly aren't going to bang down the door, as it's a waste of resources. This of course all changes if someone with the copyright starts using it again, and can potentially make money off you having downloaded it.

There's no legal definition of abandonware and the download and distribution of software that is considered abandonware is still considered theft/piracy. There's no rule under copyright law where a product eventually just becomes free.

Agreed, same with "component cables" that are just an RGB-to-YPbPr transcoder crammed inside. Just buy a single dedicated transcoder and route your consoles through that, rather than buying specialized expensive cables for _every_single_console_ and having however many redundant in-line transcoders built into each cable.

It's especially baffling with the HDMI mods. Yeah, I get it, skipping analogue altogether results in less image degradation. But is it REALLY that big of a boost, when you take into consideration how much of a pain in the ass installing those mods are, not to mention they're expensive? And unless every single console you have is getting a similar HDMI mod, you're going to have some left over that you probably need an upscaler for ANYWAY, so you might as well just save yourself the time and energy and just get normal RGB cables and run everything through a single upscaler.

- are so well known they won't benefit from the extra exposure the remake provides
- are so beloved any minor changes will piss fans off
- are so historically important people will want to play the classic version anyway

This thread is instead for those games where a remake could be a game changer that will never happen, those games you see have something special and are full of unique potential but for one reason or another are not as good as they deserved to be. Post and discuss them

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9642142
it's kind of like translating Japanese to English. Shit is like a one to many situation all of the time simply because Japanese doesn't have a lot of ways to skin a cat (especially when compared to the nightmare gobblrfuck that is English) and so you could probably take a script in Japanese, give it to 5 different translators, and get 5 different translations, depending on all manner of things. Likewise, from a single blurry texture you could get 5 different interpretations by artists.

It's the problem of having to define one answer to an open question. It's like when gunpei yokoi defended using a black and white screen on the game boy. He said that if you draw two circles on top of each other on a whiteboard and say "it's a snowman" then people will fill the gaps in their mind of what the snowman looks like. Ask one artist to draw a detailed snowman to be "the" snowman in this, and someone observing it will say that it's not what they had imagined.

This is why movie adaptations of books can often seem off vs .the originals, because you read them and have an idea of what the characters look and sound like, all for it to be torn up when you see the Hollywood version where one team of (hopefully) interested people decided what every character and element would look like and would sound like and forced it upon everyone else.
It's also why Bill Watterson fought tooth and nail against merchandise for Calvin and Hobbes; He never wanted to get to the point of making a movie or tv show and having to decide what Hobbes' voice sounded like. That was for the reader to decide as they enjoyed the comic for themselves.

tl;dr a remake can basically never change graphics in any way without potentially alienating someone because there are too many ways to take something vague and turn it into something specific and inevitably, someone will like their own interpretation of it better.

I get what he’s saying. Growing up without really using the internet I didn’t even know there was a console war. I played gameboy and NES and later on N64 and Gameboy Color and then GameCube and Gameboy Advance then Wii and DS and I just never ran out of things to play. I also wasn’t exactly rich so I hardly even came close to playing everything. Looking back at PS1 and 2s vast library I nor any of my friends, even my well off ones, had even half the games on those lists and knew of maybe only a couple of the larger ones like Metal Gear Solid they never got. Comparing something retroactively to its potential versus its actuality is a bit foolish. Games were expensive when you were a kid, piracy hardly golden. Hell, one of my friends wanted to borrow a game to pirate a copy for himself and he ended up destroying my disk, so I was very piracy averse after that experience for years. If you want to compare and argue about it now potential matters, but I don’t think it matters when you actually talk about the reality of the situation. The major difference is that it runs on a different engine. It uses the Baldur's Gate 2 engine. Its more than it seems: for all intents and purpouses it IS Baldur's Gate 2 with all the different class options, balancing, changes to magic, monster balance and behaviour, spell effects, sound effects, UI; all that stuff, but with the original Baldur's Gate campaign haphazardly stretched over it.
The original campaign was not intended to be played with all of Baldur's Gate 2's changes. Forcing them in makes the game a horrible, unbalanced thing that much less challenging, much less engaging, and much less fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9658012
>I definitely couldn't beat Diablos as soon as he's available

You can beat him at pretty much any level since his primary attack is a gravity spell. It'll drain your hit points quickly but since its damage is percentage-based it shaves off less HP every time and can't actually kill you. You'll spend the fight with alarmingly low HP but that just means you can use limit breaks on every turn which actually just makes it much easier.

He *can* physically attack and kill weakened party members but he doesn't do it often and it only ends the game if he hits the MC. If you saved the game like they told you to before using it the worst case is you reload and beat him the next time. I always beat him as soon as I get the lamp and I'm always at extremely low levels. It's a fight designed to let you win because, again, his main attack cannot kill you and you will get to use limit breaks as much as you want.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9656513
I respect this point of view, but I don't draw my line in the sand that far. If a the censorship is minor enough I'll just shrug it off.
I think the most minor case of censorship in a game I'm aware of is the Japanese version of Gyakuten Saiban. There's a bit character in one of the games who is never seen on screen named 看護婦, which means "nurse". In the DS remakes her name was changed to 看護師, which is a slightly more polite word for nurse.
I just don't feel it's worth playing the GBA version over the DS version for that one word difference.

Another example is Masoukishin, one of the early Super Robot Taisen games. My understanding is that in the DS and PSP remakes four lines of dialogue that implied that a character was a former Islamic terrorist were changed.
By playing the original over the remakes, in exchange for those four lines of dialogue, you are giving up:
>The ability to play the game on a portable system
>The ability to make a temporary save whenever you want
>96 save files
>Voices
>Very pretty art, one of the best looking games both on DS and PSP
I mean, at some point, I'm willing to look up what lines were changed and replace them with the original in my head.
I definitely wouldn't want to pay money for a game that was censored, I don't support that. But Winky Soft went out of business seven years ago so at least for that game it's a moot point.
